Pathophysiology: A type of anemia where RBC's are destroyed faster than they can be produced. It is caused by defective RBC membrane, enzyme defects, hemoglobinopathies, or extracellular effects causing RBC's to lyse and shorten their lifespan
Epidemiology: Hereditary, Acquired, Gender: Women>Men, Mainly idiopathic, Can be secondary to malignant lymphoproliferative diseases, drugs, and viral infections
Signs/Symptoms: Pallor, Tachycardia, Jaundice, Hepatosplenomegaly, Brownish discoloration of urine
Diagnostics: Normal MCV, Decreased Hgb/Hct. Increased Retic Ct, Bilirubin (indirect) and LDH. Coomb's Positive.
Treatments: Transfuse if necessary, important to find and treat underlying cause.

Pathophysiology: insufficient heme production secondary to insufficient iron supplies either due to poor diet, malabsorption, or blood loss
Epidemiology: The most common type of anemia, in pediatrics-- excessive milk intake (effects iron-binding site)
Signs/Symptoms: Fatigue, Weakness, Dyspnea on exertion, PICA (i.e., craving to eat ice, dirt,etc.), Angular Cheilitis, Koilonychia (spooning of nails)
Diagnostics: Decreased Hgb/Hct, decreased MCV, normal reticulocyte count, Decreased ferritin, Decreased iron, Increased transferrin
Treatments: Treat the cause, iron supplementation.

Pathophysiology: Genetic defect of RBC membranes resulting in spherical RBCs
Epidemiology: Autosomal dominant inheritance, Prevalent in Northern Europe and Northern America (1 in 5000 or 1 in 2000, respectively)
Signs/Symptoms: Pale skin, Fatigue, Anemia, Jaundice, Gallstones, Hepatosplenomegaly
Diagnostics: Normal Hgb, Increased MCHC, Increased osmotic fragility US: Hepatosplenomegaly, Blood Smear: Spherocytosis
Treatments: Splenectomy, Pneumococcal vaccination

Pathophysiology: Inhibition of heme synthesis by lead ingestion
Epidemiology: Half a million children are affected in USA, and is more common in children and pregnant women.
Signs/Symptoms: Fatigue, abdominal pain, short term memory loss, developmental delays, gingival lead lines, peripheral neuropathy (decreased motor control of extremities)
Diagnostics: Decreased Hgb/Hct and MCV, increased serum lead, Blood smear shows microcytic RBCs and basophilic stippling of RBCs
Treatments:
Remove source of lead; EDTA or dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA)
if needed for lead chelation (add dimercaprol in children with severe lead  intoxication)

Pathophysiology: Anemia caused by folate (vitamin B9) deficiency, secondary to low intake, often along with B12 def.
Epidemiology: More common in low economic countries, Pregnant women, Alcoholics and elderly are at risk
Signs/Symptoms:
Poor nutrition, fatigue,  dyspnea on exertion, diarrhea, sore
tongue (beefy red); pallor, increased pulse pressures
Diagnostics:
Decreased Hgb,  increased MCV, decreased serum folate,
decreased red cell folate level, decreased reticulocyte count
Blood smear: Macrocytic RBCs, hypersegmented neutrophils
Treatments: Oral folate supplements (1-5mg daily), also must replenish B12 or neurologic symptoms won't improve

Pathophysiology:
Lack of Intrinsic Factor (Pernicious Anemia)
Ileal resection (part where b12 is absorbed)
Insufficient dietary intake (vegan)
Epidemiology: Vegan, >60 yo
Signs/Symptoms: Ataxia, possible dementia, "beefy"  red tongue
Diagnostics: Megaloblastic Anemia. Decreased Hgb,  increased MCV, Macrocytic RBCs, hypersegmented neutrophils
Treatments:
Monthly intramuscular vitamin B12 injections, dietary
supplementation of vitamin B12, intranasal vitamin B12

Pathophysiology: Trapping of iron in macrophages, decreased erythropoietin production, and increased hepcidin levels
Epidemiology:
Patients with neoplasia, diabetes mellitus, autoimmune
disorders, or long-standing infections
Signs/Symptoms: Chronic disease, fatigue, weakness, dyspnea on exertion, tachycardia, pallor
Diagnostics: Mild decrease in Hgb and Hct, normal or decreased MCV, decreased iron, decreased transferrin
Treatments: Treat the underlying cause, supplemental erythropoietin

Pathophysiology: Pancytopenia caused by radiation, drugs, toxins, viral infections and congenital disorders resulting in bone marrow failure.
Epidemiology: Incidence is 1.5- 1.7 per million cases a year
Signs/Symptoms:
Fatigue, persistent infections, poor clotting with possible
uncontrolled bleeding, easy bruising, persistent menstruation, petechiae, tachycardia
Diagnostics:
Decreased Hgb, decreased white blood cells (WBCs),
decreased platelets, bone marrow biopsy shows hypocellularity and fatty infiltrate
Treatments: Stop offending agent,  transfusions, immunosuppressants and bone marrow transplant

Pathophysiology: A genetic defect of heme synthesis causing decreased Hgb levels, 10% patients progress to acute leukemia
Epidemiology: very rare
Signs/Symptoms: Fatigue, angina; pallor, tachycardia, hepatosplenomegaly, possible systolic murmur
Diagnostics: Decreased Hgb, decreased Hct, increased ferritin, increased iron, decreased transferrin, possible decreased MCV, Multiple sizes of RBCs,  ringed sideroblasts (RBC precursors) in the bone marrow
Treatments: Hereditary cases: vitamin B6, Acquired cases: supplemental erythropoietin, iron overload requires therapeutic phlebotomy or chelation with deferoxamine

Pathophysiology: Defective production of heme alpha-globin chain, chronic iron overload.
Epidemiology: More prevalent in people of Asian or African descent with variants having one or all the defective alleles
Signs/Symptoms: microcytic anemia, hemolysis, and splenomegaly. Bart's causes fetal hydrops
Diagnostics: Decreased MCV, increased reticulocyte count, increased hemoglobin, decreased oxygen releasing ability (Bart's), increased hemoglobin A2
Treatments: Usually asymptomatic, requires treatment in periods of stress, folate supplements, transfusion, iron chelation

Pathophysiology: Defective production of heme beta-globin chain, chronic iron overload
Epidemiology: More prevalent in patients of Mediterranean descents with variants have either one or two defective alleles
Signs/Symptoms: Fatigue. dyspnea. tachycardia, pallor, jaundice, irritability, slow growth
Diagnostics: Decreased MCV, increased reticulocyte count, increased hemoglobin, decreased oxygen releasing ability (Bart's), increased hemoglobin A2 or F
Treatments: Usually asymptomatic, requires treatment in periods of stress, folate supplements, transfusion, iron chelation

Pathophysiology: Defect of Hgb beta-globin chain leading to abnormal HbS characterized by sickle-shaped RBCs which undergo hemolysis under low oxygen
Epidemiology: Autosomal recessive, common in African heritage
Signs/Symptoms: Sickle cell crisis:  deep bone pain, chest pain, new stroke onset,  priapism, growth retardation, splenomegaly, jaundice
Diagnostics: Decreased Hct,  increased polymorphonuclear (PMN) cells, Hgb S without normal Hgb A; Hgb F may be increased, Radiology: “codfish” vertebrae; lung infiltrates in acute chest syndrome. Blood smear: Sickle shaped RBCs
Treatments: Hydration, supplemental O2, and analgesics, hydroxyurea, Transfusion, stem cell transplant

Pathophysiology: Hereditary condition with deficiencies of von Willebrand factor (vWF) or sometimes factor VIII leading to abnormal clotting and platelet function
Epidemiology: Autosomal dominant condition affecting 1% population of the world women>men
Signs/Symptoms: Easy bruising, mucosal bleeding (nose, gums), menorrhagia
Diagnostics:
Increased PTT, increased bleeding time, decreased factor VIII antigen,
decreased vWF antigen, decreased ristocetin cofactor activity
Treatments:
Desmopressin during minor bleeding, vWF concentrate and
factor VIII concentrate before surgery or during major bleeding, avoidance of aspirin (ASA)

Pathophysiology: Widespread abnormal coagulation caused by sepsis, severe trauma, neoplasm,, clotting factor deficiencies or obstetric complications
Epidemiology: Occur in 30-50% of patients with sepsis, Risk factors: Blood transfusion reaction. cancer, pancreatitis
Signs/Symptoms: Hematemesis,  jaundice, digital cyanosis, hypotension, neurologic or renal insufficiency signs, shock
Diagnostics:
Decreased platelets, increased PT, increased PTT, decreased fibrinogen,
increased fibrin split products, increased D-dimer
Treatments: Treat underlying cause,  platelets, FFP, cryoprecipitate; heparin

Pathophysiology: Malignant proliferation of plasma cells
Epidemiology: Increased incidence with prior monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)
Signs/Symptoms:
Back pain, radicular pain, weakness, fatigue, weight loss, constipation,
pathologic fractures, frequent infections; pallor, bone tenderness
Diagnostics: Decreased Hgb, decreased WBCs, increased blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine, increased Ca21,  high M protein and Bence Jones proteins; bone marrow biopsy shows increased plasma cells, “punched-out” lesions in long bones and skull
Treatments:
Radiation, chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant, repair of fractures,
treat infections

Pathophysiology: Increased proliferation of B-lymphocytes
Epidemiology: Bimodal age distribution (peaks at 20 and 65 yr of age),
Signs/Symptoms:
Painless lymphadenopathy (neck), weight loss,
pruritus, night sweats, fever, hepatosplenomegaly
Diagnostics: Lymph node biopsy shows Reed-Sternberg cells
Treatments: Radiation, chemotherapy

Pathophysiology: Proliferation of Lymphocytes, commonly B cells or natural killer cells.
Epidemiology:
Incidence 1 in 41, common in women than men, Risk factors: EBV, HIV, congenital immunodeficiencies, rheumatic
disease
Signs/Symptoms:
Painless lymphadenopathy (generalized), weight loss, fever,
night sweats
Diagnostics:
Lymph node or bone marrow biopsy: lymphocyte
proliferation (cleaved cells seen in follicular small cell
variant)
Treatments: Palliative radiation, chemotherapy

Pathophysiology: Proliferation of cells of lymphoid origin (lymphocytes)
Epidemiology: Most common in children (2 to 5 years of age); whites . blacks
Signs/Symptoms:
Bone pain, frequent infections, fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, easy
bruising; fever, pallor, purpura, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy
Diagnostics: Decreased Hgb, decreased platelets and WBCs, increased uric acid, increased LDH; bone marrow biopsy: abundant blasts; Philadelphia chromosome (i.e., translocation of chromosomes 9 and 22 in BCR-ABL genes)
Treatments: Chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant

Pathophysiology: Proliferation of myeloid cells
Epidemiology: Both adults and children are affected
Signs/Symptoms: Easy bruising, oral petechiae, frequent infections, arthralgias; fever,  hepatosplenomegaly, mucosal bleeding, ocular hemorrhages
Diagnostics: Decreased Hgb, decreased platelets, decreased WBCs; bone marrow biopsy: blast cells  of myeloid origin, Blood smear: large myeloblasts with notched nuclei and Auer rods
Treatments: Chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant

Pathophysiology: Malignant transformation of lymphoid cells (mature B-cells) involving bloodstream and bone marrow
Epidemiology: In patients with >65 years of age, worldwide incidence < 1 and 5.5 per 100,000
Signs/Symptoms:
Frequent infection (secondary to no plasma cells), night sweats;
fevers, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly
Diagnostics:
Increased WBCs (may be .100,000/mL); bone marrow:
lymphocyte infiltration, numerous small lymphocytes, smudge cells
Treatments:
Supportive therapy, chemotherapy, radiation for bulky lymphoid
masses, splenectomy

Pathophysiology: Rh incompatibility disorder caused by different Rh factors of mother and the fetus resulting in RBC hemolysis in newborn
Epidemiology: Incidence is 3-80 in 100,000, Risk factors: Rh2 mother with any history of fetal–maternal hemorrhage
Signs/Symptoms:
Pale skin. yellowing of the amniotic fluid, umbilical cord, jaundice
Hepatosplenomegaly. severe swelling of the body (hydrop fetalis)
Diagnostics: Rh positive antibodies in  blood. Ultrasound.: enlarged organs or fluid buildup in baby. Amniocentesis, Percutaneous umbilical cord blood sampling.
Treatments:
Administration of Rho(D) immune globulin (RhoGAM) within 72 hr
of delivery of initial Rh1 fetus

Pathophysiology: Disorder of bone marrow resulting in pancytopenia, increased risk of leukemia
Epidemiology: Autosomal recessive, incidence 1 in 160,000 worldwide, common in Ashkenazi Jewish descent, the Roma population of Spain, and Black South Africans
Signs/Symptoms:
Frequent infections, short stature, café-au-lait spots on skin 
(hypopigmented areas), horseshoe kidney, and thumb abnormalities
Diagnostics: Decreased Hgb, platelets, and WBCs; increased serum a-Fetoprotein;bone marrow biopsy: hypocellularity,
Treatments: Antibiotics, transfusions, bone marrow/stem cell transplant, hematopoietic growth factors; androgens and corticosteroids

Pathophysiology: Congenital RBC anemia due to a defect in erythroid progenitor cells
Epidemiology: Approximately 5-7 people per million live births/year
Signs/Symptoms: Craniofacial abnormalities, thumb abnormalities, heart murmurs, mental retardation, hypogonadism
Diagnostics: Decreased Hgb, increased MCV; bone marrow biopsy: decreased activity but increased presence of erythropoietin
Treatments: Transfusions, corticosteroids, bone marrow transplant

Pathophysiology: Most common extracranial childhood tumor of Neural crest cell origin affecting adrenal glands or sympathetic ganglia
Epidemiology: Incidence is 1 in 7000, Risk factors: neurofibromatosis, tuberous sclerosis, pheochromocytoma, low maternal folate consumption
Signs/Symptoms:
Abdominal distention and pain, weight loss, bone pain, diarrhea;
abdominal mass, possible Horner syndrome, proptosis,  periorbital bruising
Diagnostics:
Increased vanillylmandelic and homovanillic acids in 24-hr urine
collection, Radiology: CT may locate adrenal or ganglion tumor
Treatments: Surgical resection, chemotherapy, radiation

Pathophysiology: Tumor of striated muscle in children
Epidemiology: Most common soft tissue tumors, children < 10
Signs/Symptoms: Painful soft tissue mass with swelling; compression of the adjacent structures by large tumors
Diagnostics: Biopsy is diagnostic, Radiology: CT or MRI for the extent of tumor
Treatments: Surgical debulking, radiation, chemotherapy

Pathophysiology: Permanent end of menstruation because of ceasing of ovarian function in later middle age (51.5 years)
Epidemiology: naturally occurs in women between 49 to 52 of age
Signs/Symptoms: Hot flashes, breast pain, menstrual irregularity with eventual amenorrhea, menorrhagia, irritability, depression, dyspareunia
Diagnostics: Increased FSH, increased LH, decreased estradiol
Treatments: Lubricating agents to treat dyspareunia, Calcium, vitamin D, bisphosphonates, and exercise to prevent osteoporosis, raloxifene and tamoxifen

Pathophysiology: Absence of menstruation
Epidemiology: Prevalence is 3,000-4,000/100,000 individuals
Signs/Symptoms: secondary: > six months without menses
Diagnostics: Tanner stages, b-hCG test, Thyroid studies, FSH and LH levels
Treatments: treat the underlying cause

Pathophysiology: Syndrome in women with normal functioning ovaries that precede menses, are characterized by multiple pain, mood, and autonomic symptoms
Epidemiology: 5% to 10% of women have severe symptoms that interfere with daily life.
Signs/Symptoms: Weight gain, abdominal or pelvic pain,  change in bowel habits, food cravings, mood lability, depression
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination
Treatments: Exercise, vitamin B6, NSAIDs, OCPs, progestins, SSRIs

Pathophysiology: Presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus
Epidemiology: Risk factors: family history, infertility, nulliparity, low body mass index
Signs/Symptoms: Dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dyschezia, pelvic pain, uterine or adnexal tenderness
Diagnostics: Biopsy shows endometrial tissue; b-hCG to rule out pregnancy, CA-125 marker increased, laparoscopy show “powder-burn” lesions and cysts
Treatments: OCPs, progestins, danazol, or GnRH agonists may supply symptomatic relief, Laparoscopic ablation, hysterectomy

Pathophysiology: Irregular and excessive menstruation
Epidemiology: 10% to 30% among women of reproductive age.
Signs/Symptoms: Uterine bleeding that does not follow a usual menstrual cycle, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, acne, bleeding at the site
Diagnostics: b-hCG used to rule out pregnancy, (CBC), coagulation studies, TSH, FSH, and LH are used, Papanicolaou (Pap) smear and endometrial biopsy used to rule out cancer, US for uterine lesions
Treatments: Treat underlying disorder, OCPs, Endometrial ablation

Pathophysiology: Hypothalamic-pituitary disease characterized by anovulation
Epidemiology: Up to 10% of women are diagnosed with PCOS
Signs/Symptoms: Obesity, Hirsutism: excess growth of facial, chest, and abdominal hair, Acne, amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, Bilateral ovarian enlargement on bimanual examination
Diagnostics: Increased LH, LH:FSH ratio, increased DHEA, increased total testosterone; positive progestin challenge, US shows enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts
Treatments: Exercise and weight loss, OCPs, Spironolactone, Clomiphene, Metformin, Antibiotics as needed for acne

Pathophysiology: Vaginal infection caused by overgrowth of normal bacteria  protozoans, fungus
Epidemiology: Risk factors: DM, HIV, unprotected sex,, young age at first intercourse, douching, intrauterine device (IUD) use, smoking
Signs/Symptoms: vaginal irritation or pruritus, vaginal discharge; examination detects vaginal inflammation
Diagnostics: Wet mount with saline or potassium hydroxide (KOH) and vaginal pH testing, “whiff test”
Treatments: Metronidazole, clindamycin, fluconazole

Pathophysiology: Severe systemic reaction to Staphylococcus aureus exotoxin associated with prolonged tampon use, prolonged intravaginal, etc
Epidemiology: Infants and the elderly are at highest risk
Signs/Symptoms:
Sore throat, macular rash; hypotension, shock, respiratory distress, 
and palmoplantar desquamation
Diagnostics: Culture shows S. aureus; decreased platelets, increased ALT and AST, and increased (BUN) and creatinine
Treatments: Remove tampon/ intravaginal objects, Supportive care for hypotension, Clindamycin or penicillinase-resistant b-lactam antibiotics, vancomycin r

Pathophysiology: Infection of cervical columnar epithelium caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis
Signs/Symptoms: Asymptomatic, Dyspareunia, bleeding after intercourse, purulent vaginal discharge, Urethritis, inflammation of cervix
Diagnostics: Gram stain  shows gram-negative diplococci with N. gonorrhoeae, Culture on Thayer-Martin agar detects N. gonorrhoeae,
Treatments: Ceftriaxone, doxycycline or azithromycin

Pathophysiology:
Progressive N. gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia infection resulting in involvement of ovaries, uterus, fallopian tubes, or peritoneal cavity

Risk factors: multiple sexual partners, unprotected intercourse, prior PID, douching, young age at first intercourse
Epidemiology:
An estimated 750,000 new cases occur annually.
Risk factors: multiple sexual partners, unprotected intercourse, prior PID, douching, young age at first intercourse
Signs/Symptoms: Lower abdominal pain, dysuria; purulent cervical discharge, adnexal tenderness, abdominal guarding
Diagnostics: Pregnancy test to rule out ectopic pregnancy, Increased WBC and ESR, Culdocentesis yields pus. transvaginal US detect inflamed and enlarged uterus, laparoscopy
Treatments: Empiric antibiotics, treat as an inpatient if high fevers or young age; treat sexual partners

Pathophysiology: Disease caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum (only transmitted by sexual contact or vertical transmission)
Epidemiology: 15.6 cases per 100,000 males and 1.9 cases per 100,000 females
Signs/Symptoms:
Solitary chancre, maculopapular rash on palms and soles, 
lArgyll-Robertson pupils
Diagnostics: VDRL and RPR are 80% sensitive screening tests, FTA-ABS or MHA-TP used to confirm diagnosis, Spirochetes may be seen with dark-field microscopy
Treatments:
Penicillin G, doxycycline, or tetracycline; IV penicillin G used in 
severe tertiary cases

Pathophysiology: Several types of papillomavirus (<100) that may be associated with genital warts (types 6 and 11) or cervical cancer (types 16 or 18 in 70% of cases)
Epidemiology: 6.2 million new HPV infections occur every year in the United States
Signs/Symptoms: Small pink papules at site of contact; Warts on genital region
Diagnostics: An abnormal Pap smear should prompt HPV testing and colposcopy for lesions, acetic acid to lesions will turn them white, Biopsy determine virus type
Treatments:
Podophyllin, trichloroacetic acid, topical 5-fluorouracil, a-interferon 
injection of large lesions, cryotherapy, or laser therapy;  vaccine

Pathophysiology: Disease caused by L-1, L-2, or L-3 serotypes of C. trachomatis
Epidemiology: more common in developing nations
Signs/Symptoms: Formation of papule at site of contact that becomes painless ulcer, inguinal buboes develop, progress to bubo ulceration, elephantiasis  fistula formation, abscess formation
Diagnostics: Immunoassays for Chlamydia for diagnosis
Treatments: Tetracycline, erythromycin, or doxycycline

Pathophysiology: Benign uterine masses composed of smooth muscle
Epidemiology: Risk factors: nulliparity, African-American heritage, a diet high in meats, alcohol,consumption, family history
Signs/Symptoms: Asymptomatic, menorrhagia, pelvic pain, urinary frequency
Diagnostics: Palpable mass on examination, transvaginal US or hysteroscopy to visualize mass
Treatments: GnRH agonists, Myomectomy, Hysterectomy, Uterine artery embolization

Pathophysiology: Adenocarcinoma of uterine tissue most commonly related to exposure to high estrogen levels;
Epidemiology:
Most common in postmenopausal women
Risk factors: PCOS, obesity, nulliparity, DM, HTN, increased age (postmenopausal), high-fat diet, colon cancer
Signs/Symptoms: Heavy menses, midcycle bleeding, or postmenopausal bleeding
Diagnostics: Endometrial biopsy, increased CA-125 tumor marker, CXR/CT  used to detect metastases; transvaginal US to detect masses
Treatments: Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH-BSO), Chemotherapy, Hormone therapy (e.g., progesterone, tamoxifen)

Pathophysiology: Squamous cell cancer (80% cases), adenocarcinoma (15% cases), or mixed adenosquamous carcinoma (5% cases) of the cervix that results from progression of cervical dysplasia
Epidemiology: risk factors: early first intercourse, HPV 16:18 are high risk
Signs/Symptoms: Vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or cervical discharge; cervical mass
Diagnostics: Punch biopsy of visible lesions; cone biopsy determines invasion extent, CT/MRI/US useful to measure extent of disease
Treatments: Chemotherapy, radiotherapy, supportive therapy, hysterectomy,

Pathophysiology: Cancer of ovaries most commonly of epithelial (65% cases) or germ cell (25% cases) origin
Epidemiology: Risk factors: family history, infertility, nulliparity, BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutations
Signs/Symptoms: Usually asymptomatic, Abdominal pain, fatigue, weight loss, change in bowel habits, menstrual irregularity; ascites
Diagnostics: increased CA-125, a-fetoprotein, hCG, LDH, US used to detect mass; MRI or CT useful to determine the extent of involvement
Treatments: TAH/BSO, adjuvant chemotherapy, tumor debulking, oophorectomy

Pathophysiology: Most common benign breast tumor
Epidemiology: More common in women, 30 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Solitary, solid, and mobile mass with well-defined edges; size may vary during menstrual cycle
Diagnostics: Biopsy (FNA or open) confirms benign nature, US, mammogram/MRI for the location of mass
Treatments: Surgical excision or US-guided cryotherapy

Pathophysiology: New onset glucose intolerance that begins during pregnancy (after 24 weeks)
Epidemiology: Risk factors: family history of DM, obesity, prior polyhydramnios, recurrent abortions, African or Pacific Islander heritage,
Signs/Symptoms: usually asymptomatic
Diagnostics: Fasting glucose >126 mg/dL or abnormal glucose tolerance test performed at 24 to 28 weeks’ gestation
Treatments:
Strict glucose control through diet and exercise, Insulin, 
C-section for macrosomic babies.

Pathophysiology: Pregnancy-induced HTN with proteinuria and edema
Epidemiology: In 5% of pregnancies owing to an unknown cause, Risk factors: HTN, nulliparity, prior history of preeclampsia, multiple gestation, vascular disease, African-American ancestry
Signs/Symptoms:
Edema in hands and face, rapid weight gain, epigastric abdominal 
pain, visual disturbances, hyperreflexia, Blood pressure >140/90 mm
Diagnostics: Urinalysis shows proteinuria, Decreased platelets, normal/increased creatinine, increased ALT and AST, decreased GFR
Treatments: If a near term, induce delivery, antiHTN, MgSO4, Ca channel blockers

Pathophysiology: Progression of preeclampsia leading to maternal seizures that can be severe and fatal for both mother and child if untreated
Epidemiology: Global incidence of preeclampsia is 5-14%
Signs/Symptoms: Headaches, scotomata, upper abdominal pain, seizures
Diagnostics: Elevated Blood pressure, proteinuria, low platelet count, elevated PT and aPTT
Treatments: Labor should be induced, Use MgSO4 and IV diazepam to control seizures., Stabilize patient with O2, antihypertensive,

Pathophysiology: Fetal growth that lags behind gestational age (10th percentile)
Epidemiology: second leading cause of perinatal morbidity and mortality
Signs/Symptoms: Fundal height is at least 3 cm smaller than expected, the US shows growth ratios to be asymmetric, Doppler US show decreased fetal, umbilical, or maternal blood flow.
Diagnostics: Ultrasound with or without doppler
Treatments: Fetal growth should be monitored, Nutritional supplementation, maternal O2 therapy, and maternal bed rest, induced labor, Maternal antenatal corticosteroids

Pathophysiology: Spontaneous rupture of amniotic sac with spillage of amniotic fluid before onset of labor
Epidemiology: Risk factors: vaginal or cervical infection, cervical incompetence, poor maternal nutrition
Signs/Symptoms: Loss of amniotic fluid from vagina; amniotic fluid may be seen pooling in vagina on visual examination
Diagnostics:
“ferning” of amniotic fluid; vaginal fluid will turn nitrazine paper blue in presence of amniotic 
fluid; Radiology: the US confirms oligohydramnios and assess volume 
of residual amniotic fluid and fetal position
Treatments: Give corticosteroids for fetal lung maturation and prophylactic antibiotics, induce labor

Pathophysiology: Implantation of placenta near cervical os frequently associated with vaginal bleeding.
Epidemiology:
Risk factors: multiparity, increased maternal age, prior 
placenta previa, prior C-section,  uterine fibroids, history of abortion, smoking
Signs/Symptoms: Painless vaginal bleeding in third trimester
Diagnostics: Radiology: US determines location of placenta
Treatments:
Bed rest, maternal and fetal monitoring; Rho(D) immune globulin 
to Rh-negative mother, Tocolytics

Pathophysiology: Acute skin infection most frequently caused by Staphylococcus aureus or group A streptococci or MRSA
Epidemiology: Risk factors: I/V drug use, DM, Immunosuppression, previous cellulitis, venous or lymphatic dysfunction
Signs/Symptoms: Erythema, swollen and painful skin, myalgias, chills; warmth in involved area, lymphadenopathy
Diagnostics: Increased WBC, ESR and CRP
Treatments:
oral cephalosporins or penicillinase-resistant b-lactams for 10 to 
14 days; intravenous (IV) antibiotics for severe cases or bacteremia; linezolid or 
IV vancomycin used for MRSA or cases not responding to initial antibiotic therapy; 
diabetics should receive broad coverage antibiotics because of the increased risk for 
multiorganism infections

Pathophysiology: Streptococcus A or multi pathogen infection of fascial planes leading to extensive soft tissue destruction and systemic infection
Epidemiology: Adults incidence 0.40 cases per 100,000 people/year
Signs/Symptoms: Erythematous, warm, swollen skin; hypoaesthesia of involved tissue, crepitus in infected skin, purple discoloration, bullae
Diagnostics:
Increased WBC, ESR, and CRP; culture sensitivity test, 
X-ray/CT may detect subcutaneous collections of air
Treatments: Surgical debridement, incision, and drainage; IV antibiotics

Pathophysiology: Poststreptococcal and poststaphylococcal skin infection
Epidemiology: 2.8 percent in children up to four years of age and 1.6 percent among children five to 15 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Facial pruritus; yellow crusted lesions around mucocutaneous surfaces; blisters, erythematous pustules on face and extremities
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination, gram stain, culture and sensitivity, Anti-DNA-ase B Test
Treatments: Maintain hygiene, oral or topical antibiotics, limit the spread

Pathophysiology: Inflammation of hair follicles and sebaceous glands
Epidemiology: Prevalence (for all ages) of 9.38%, Most frequently occurs in adolescents
Signs/Symptoms: Erythematous pustules on the face, neck, chest, and back, Cystic lesions can form in severe cases.
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination
Treatments: Topical retinoids, Antibiotics (oral or topical), Benzoyl peroxide, Oral contraceptives, Oral isotretinoin, Soaps and astringents

Pathophysiology: Viral skin infection in children and in patients positive for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
Epidemiology: most common in children 1 to 10 years of age
Signs/Symptoms:
Painless, shiny papules with central umbilication 
found on the face, back, chest, and extremities in children; in adults, found in perineal region
Diagnostics: Giemsa and Wright stains show large inclusion bodies
Treatments: Self-limited; chemical, laser, or cryotherapy for removal

Pathophysiology: Cutaneous infestation by Sarcoptes scabiei mite
Epidemiology: prevalence of 5–10% in children, Risk factors: crowded living conditions, poor hygiene
Signs/Symptoms: Pruritus at site of involvement, papules on the skin
Diagnostics: Mites and eggs may be seen in skin scrapings under microscope
Treatments: Permethrin cream or oral ivermectin; diphenhydramine, all clothing, towels, and linens must be washed in hot water.

Pathophysiology: generalized URI from various influenza strains
Epidemiology: All ages, higher risk for very young and very old
Signs/Symptoms: arthralgia, myalgias, sore throat, high fevers
Diagnostics: rapid antigen testing, pcr more sensitive but takes longer
Treatments: vaccination, tamiflu may shorten duration of disease, supportive care

Pathophysiology: infection of sinus cavities, usually viral (90-98%), but can be Strep, Haemophilus, or M. Catarrhalis.
Epidemiology: All ages, usually > 8 yo
Signs/Symptoms: pain over infected sinuses, purulent nasal discharge
Diagnostics: clinical, but CT may show opacification of infected sinus
Treatments: amoxicillin or other pcn, for chronic may need longer course

Pathophysiology: Inflammation of trachea and bronchi caused by the spread of URI or exposure to inhaled irritants
Epidemiology: 44 of 1000 adults annually
Signs/Symptoms: Productive cough, sore throat; fever, wheezing, tight breath sounds
Diagnostics: Sputum culture, CXR may show only mild congestion
Treatments: Self-limited if viral, antibiotics

Pathophysiology: Infection of the bronchoalveolar tree can be caused by common nasopharyngeal bacteria or bacteria, viruses, or fungi
Epidemiology: 1.5 to 14/1000 community-acquired pneumonia persons/years
Signs/Symptoms: Pleuritic chest pain; rales, wheezing, egophony, tactile fremitus, tachypnea
Diagnostics:
Increased WBC with left shift; positive sputum and blood culture
CXR shows lobar consolidation, infiltrates, or general increased density of lung fields
Treatments:
viral pneumonia is self-limited, requires supportive care;
antibiotics, antifungal

Pathophysiology: Pulmonary infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Epidemiology: 10 new cases per 100,000 people each year, Risk factors: immunosuppression, alcoholism, lung disease, DM, advanced age,  crowded living conditions, and close proximity to infected patients
Signs/Symptoms: Hemoptysis, dyspnea, weight loss, night sweats; fever, rales
Diagnostics:
PPD tuberculin skin test is a screening test for exposure, positive sputum acid-fast stain, positive culture, bronchoscopy 
CXR show apical fibronodular infiltrates, lower-lobe infiltrates, Ghon complexes
Treatments: Respiratory isolation for any inpatient; multidrug treatment initially with isoniazid (INH), rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol followed by INH and rifampin only for a total of 6 months; vitamin B6, DOT therapy for non-complaint patients

Pathophysiology: Lower respiratory tract infection caused by bacteria
Epidemiology: 900,000 people each year
Signs/Symptoms: High fever, productive cough, chills, dyspnea, loss of appetite, chest pain
Diagnostics: focal lung exam: crackles, bronchial breath sounds, or dullness to percussion, CBC; Increased WBCs, CXR: White spots, Culture sensitivity to confirm bacteria
Treatments: Empiric therapy, macrolides, supportive therapy

Pathophysiology: Lower respiratory tract infection caused by atypical bacteria such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydophila pneumoniae and Legionella pneumophilia
Signs/Symptoms: Flu-like symptoms, headache, fatigue myalgias
Diagnostics: Focal lung exam: crackles, bronchial breath sounds, or dullness to percussion, CBC; Increased WBCs, CXR: White spots, Culture sensitivity to confirm bacteria
Treatments: Empiric therapy, Macrolides, supportive therapy

Pathophysiology: Reversible airway obstruction secondary to bronchial hyperactivity, acute airway inflammation, mucus plugging, and smooth muscle hypertrophy
Epidemiology:
20 million U.S. adults age 18 and over 
Risk factors: family history of asthma, allergies, atopic dermatitis, low socioeconomic status
Signs/Symptoms: Wheezing, chest tightness; prolonged expiratory duration, wheezing, accessory muscle use,  pulsus paradoxus;
Diagnostics: PEFR decreased, PFT shows decreased FEV1, normal/elevated DLco;  respiratory alkalosis, CXR shows hyperinflation
Treatments: Bronchodilators, cortecosteroids, avoidance of exacerbating factors

Pathophysiology: Chronic bronchial inflammation associated with tobacco use chronic asthma
Signs/Symptoms: Productive cough, recurrent respiratory infections, dyspnea; rhonchi
Diagnostics: History of productive cough for 3 months, PFTs show gradually worsening signs of obstructive disease
Treatments: Tobacco cessation, antibiotics, bronchodilators

Pathophysiology: Destruction of alveoli and bronchioles resulting in panacinar airspace enlargement and a decreased capillary bed, Less commonly caused by a1-antitrypsin deficiency
Epidemiology: Prevalence  in the US is approximately 14 million,
Signs/Symptoms: Morning headache; barrel chested, pursed-lip breathing, prolonged expiratory duration, rhonchi, JVD
Diagnostics:
PFT shows decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1/FVC, increased total
lung capacity (TLC), CXR shows flat diaphragm,  subpleural blebs and bullae a
Treatments: Smoking cessation; supplemental O2; b2-agonists; inhaled corticosteroids; antibiotics

Pathophysiology: Permanent dilation of small and medium bronchi because of the destruction of bronchial elastic components
Epidemiology: 350,000 to 500,000 adults in the US
Signs/Symptoms: Hemoptysis, respiratory infections, copious sputum,  rales, and hypoxemia,  multiple cysts and bronchial crowding on CXR; CT shows dilation of bronchi, bronchial wall thickening
Diagnostics: History and physical examination, CXR or CT
Treatments: pulmonary hygiene, chest physical therapy; antibiotics, corticosteroids

Pathophysiology: Idiopathic Inflammatory lung disease causing lung fibrosis
Epidemiology: Generally affects patients 50 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Exercise intolerance, dyspnea; dry crackles, JVD, tachypnea, digital clubbing
Diagnostics: FEV1/FVC normal, decreased FVC, decreased TLC, fibrosis on lung biopsy, CXR shows “honeycomb” lung, CT will show “ground glass” appearance
Treatments: corticosteroids, azathioprine or cyclophosphamide, lung transplant

Pathophysiology: Idiopathic systemic disease characterized by noncaseating granulomas
Epidemiology: Risk factors: blacks >whites; females>males; most frequently occurs between 10 and 40 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Weight loss, arthritis, chest pain; erythema nodosum, lymphadenopathy, vision loss, cranial nerve palsies
Diagnostics: Increased serum ACE, hypercalciuria, increased alkaline phosphatase, decreased WBC, increased ESR; CXR shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary infiltrates
Treatments: Corticosteroids, cytotoxic drugs, lung transplantation

Pathophysiology: Progressive autoimmune disease of lungs and kidneys caused by antiglomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies
Epidemiology: incidence of 0.5-1.8/million/year in European white and Asians,  predominantly affects the white population, with bimodal age distribution in 20 - 30 years and 60 - 70 years old.
Signs/Symptoms: Hemoptysis, dyspnea, recent respiratory infection
Diagnostics: positive anti-GBM antibodies; renal biopsy shows crescentic glomerulonephritis, CXR shows bilateral alveolar infiltration
Treatments:
plasmapheresis to remove autoantibodies; corticosteroids and
immunosuppressive agents

Pathophysiology: Rare disease with granulomatous inflammation and necrosis of lung and other organ system
Epidemiology: annual incidence rates from 3 to 14 per million
Signs/Symptoms: hemoptysis, ulcerations of the nasopharynx, fever; mild hematuria, sensory neuropathy, cranial nerve dysfunction conjunctivitis, proptosis, arrhythmia
Diagnostics: positive c-ANCA, noncaseating granulomas; renal biopsy detects vasculitic process
Treatments: Cytotoxic therapy, corticosteroids

Pathophysiology: Occlusion of pulmonary vasculature by a dislodged thrombus
Epidemiology: Risk factors: immobilization, cancer, prolonged travel, recent surgery,  hypercoagulability,  fractures
Signs/Symptoms: Pleuritic chest pain, cough, syncope, feeling of impending doom; loud S2,
Diagnostics: Increased D-dimer, ECG shows tachycardia, CXR show wedge-shaped infarct
Treatments: Supplemental O2, IV fluids for hypotension; anticoagulant therapy;

Pathophysiology: Tumor occurring on visceral pleura or pericardium with very poor prognosis
Epidemiology: Increased incidence with asbestos exposure (occurs 20 years after exposure), especially in smokers
Signs/Symptoms: nonpleuritic chest pain, dullness to percussion over lung bases, palpable chest wall mass, scoliosis
Diagnostics:
pleural biopsy; thoracocentesis for pleural effusion effusion 
CXR shows pleural thickening, pleural effusion; CT display the extent
Treatments:
extrapleural pneumonectomy with adjuvant chemotherapy and
radiation therapy

Pathophysiology: Episodic cessation of airflow during sleep leading to desaturations and frequent arousals
Epidemiology: Risk factors: obesity, sedative use; males more than females
Signs/Symptoms: Excessive daytime sleepiness, snoring, gasping or choking during sleep,  obesity common, anatomic abnormalities of palate or pharynx
Diagnostics: Epworth sleepiness scale predicting likelihood of sleep apnea, polysomnography, Sao2, and number of arousals
Treatments: Bariatric surgery in obesity, CPAP, tracheostomy, respiratory stimulants; phrenic nerve pacemaking may be needed in severe  cases

Pathophysiology: Acute inflammation of larynx, typically parainfluenza
Epidemiology: Most common between 3 months and 5 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Nasal congestion, barking cough, mild pharyngeal erythema, lymphadenopathy
Diagnostics: Steeple sign on XR
Treatments: supportive care, aerosolized epinephrine and glucocorticoids

Pathophysiology: Rapidly progressive infection of the epiglottis and surrounding tissues that can cause airway obstruction
Epidemiology: Most common in children from 2 to 7 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: dysphagia, drooling, soft stridor, muffled voice, inspiratory retractions, erythematous and swollen epiglottis
Diagnostics: Neck radiographs show swollen, opacified epiglottis (thumbprint sign);
Treatments: Intubate (nasotracheal) to maintain airway patency; antibiotics, emergent tracheostomy

Pathophysiology: Viral infection of bronchioles, commonly RSV
Epidemiology: Commonly occurs in winter and spring; usually found in children <2 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Nasal congestion, respiratory distress, prolonged expiration, hyper resonance to percussion
Diagnostics: rapid RSV, CXR shows hyperinflation of lungs and patchy infiltrates
Treatments: Hydration, humidified air; bronchodilators

Pathophysiology: surfactant deficiency because of lung immaturity that leads to decreased lung compliance
Epidemiology: preterm infants
Signs/Symptoms: Nasal flaring, expiratory grunting, intercostal retractions, respiratory rate >60 breaths/min, crackles
Diagnostics: ABG shows increased CO2, decreased O2, sphingomyelin ratio,  CXR shows bilateral atelectasis with ground glass appearance and decreased lung volumes
Treatments: maternal administration of corticosteroids, supplemental O2 and surfactant replacement therapy, intubation

Pathophysiology: Aspiration of meconium  causing obstruction of airways and pneumonia
Epidemiology: newborns
Signs/Symptoms: meconium-stained amniotic fluid; cyanosis, intercostal retractions; distended chest
Diagnostics: Blood culture to rule out sepsis, CXR shows atelectasis, areas of hyperinflation, or pneumothorax
Treatments: Suction nose, mouth, and upper airway at birth; supplemental O2; surfactant therapy, +/- empiric antibiotic therapy

Pathophysiology: Autosomal recessive disorder caused by defect in chloride-pumping channel in exocrine glands
Epidemiology: Risk factors: whites at higher risk than other races
Signs/Symptoms: recurrent pulmonary infections, hemoptysis, chronic sinusitis, steatorrhea, digital clubbing, esophageal varices, rectal prolapse
Diagnostics: Decreased serum Na; sweat test shows increased Na and increased Cl, mutated CFTR gene
Treatments:
DNase aids in decreasing the viscosity of secretions; chest physical therapy, bronchodilators, NSAIDs, antibiotics s and vitamins A, D, E,
and K

Pathophysiology: Infection of renal parenchyma, most commonly caused by bacteria and fungi
Epidemiology:
Annual rates of 15-17/10,000 females and 3-4/10,000 males in US.
Risk factors: urinary obstruction, immunocompromised, history of DM
Signs/Symptoms: Flank pain, chills, urinary frequency, dysuria, urgency; fever (>101.5°F/38°C), costovertebral tenderness
Diagnostics: Increased WBC, ESR, CRP; WBC casts in urine; positive urine cultures
Treatments: IV fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides, or cephalosporins

Pathophysiology: Formation of “kidney” stones; stone formation can also occur elsewhere in the urinary tract causing obstruction.
Epidemiology: Risk factors:  prior nephrolithiasis, low fluid intake, frequent UTIs, gout, renal tubular acidosis, hypercalcemia,  males > females
Signs/Symptoms: Acute severe colicky flank pain that may extend to inner thigh or genitals, gross hematuria
Diagnostics: Urinalysis shows hematuria, abdominal X-ray shows stones, CT/US to locate stones; intravenous pyelogram (IVP) shows filling defect
Treatments: Hydration and pain control, shockwave lithotripsy, surgery

Pathophysiology: Hereditary syndrome characterized by the formation of cysts in one or both kidneys leading to eventual kidney function impairment and failure
Epidemiology:
Autosomal dominant: most common form; affects adults
Autosomal recessive: rare form; presents in children
Signs/Symptoms: asymptomatic, flank pain, chronic UTI, gross hematuria; large, palpable kidneys
Diagnostics: Increased BUN  and creatinine, anemia; urinalysis shows hematuria and proteinuria, US/CT will show large multicystic kidneys
Treatments: vasopressin receptor antagonists and amiloride, drainage of large cysts; dialysis or transplant

Pathophysiology: Damage of renal tubules or parenchyma caused by drugs, toxins, infection, or autoimmune processes
Epidemiology: three general categories: drug-induced, infection-associated, and cases associated with immune or neoplastic disorders
Signs/Symptoms: Symptoms of acute kidney injury, rash; fever
Diagnostics: Increased Cr, eosinophilia; granular or epithelial casts on urine analysis, renal biopsy shows infiltration of inflammatory cells and renal tubular necrosis
Treatments: Treat the cause, supportive care, corticosteroids

Pathophysiology: Sequelae of systemic infection (most commonly group A streptococcus)
Epidemiology: Incidence 8.5 to 28.5 per 100000 individuals. more in males than females
Signs/Symptoms: Recent infection, oliguria, edema, brown urine, hypertension;
Diagnostics: Hematuria and proteinuria in urinalysis, high ASO titer, subepithelial “humps” of IgG and C3 on renal basement membrane
Treatments:
Self-limited, supportive treatment (decrease edema
and hypertension)

Pathophysiology: Idiopathic deposition of IgA immune complexes in mesangial cells
Epidemiology: Rare in the US and Europe, common in Asia and the Middle East.  12.6-20/100,000 people in the US
Signs/Symptoms: Hematuria, flank pain, low-grade fever
Diagnostics: Increased serum IgA, mesangial cell proliferation on electron microscopy
Treatments:
Occasionally self-limited; give ACE-I and statins for
persistent proteinuria; corticosteroids

Pathophysiology: Progressive autoimmune disease of lungs and kidneys caused by anti-GBM antibodies characterized by intra-alveolar hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis
Epidemiology: Incidence of 0.5 - 1.8 cases per million per year in European white and Asians, the bimodal age distribution in 20 - 30 years and 60 - 70 years old
Signs/Symptoms: Hemoptysis, dyspnea, recent respiratory infection
Diagnostics: positive anti-GBM antibodies; proteinuria and granular casts; renal biopsy shows crescentic glomerulonephritis and IgG deposition along glomerular capillaries, CXR shows bilateral alveolar infiltration
Treatments: Plasmapheresis, corticosteroids, immunosuppressants

Pathophysiology: Hereditary defect in collagen IV in basement membrane
Epidemiology: 1 in 5,000-10,000 people in US
Signs/Symptoms: Hematuria, symptoms of renal failure, high-frequency hearing loss, cataracts, lenticonus
Diagnostics: Red cell casts, hematuria, proteinuria, and pyuria on urinalysis; “split basement membrane” on electron microscopy
Treatments: ACE-I may reduce proteinuria; renal transplant

Pathophysiology: Rapidly progressive renal failure from idiopathic causes or associated with other glomerular diseases or systemic infection
Epidemiology: The annual incidence of RPGN is 0.7/100,000.
Signs/Symptoms:
Sudden renal failure, weakness, nausea, weight loss, dyspnea,
hemoptysis, myalgias, fever, oliguria
Diagnostics: Inflammatory cells deposition and fibrosis of Bowman capsule, and basement membrane wrinkling on electron microscopy; pauci-immune RPGN is ANCA1
Treatments: Corticosteroids, plasmapheresis, immunosuppressants, renal transplant frequently

Pathophysiology: Complication of SLE involving proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells
Epidemiology: Incidence 7.4-159.4 cases per 100,000 people
Signs/Symptoms: Asymptomatic, HTN or renal failure; may develop nephrotic syndrome
Diagnostics: ANA, anti-DNA antibodies; hematuria, proteinuria
Treatments: Corticosteroids, immunosuppressive agents, ACE-I reduce proteinuria

Pathophysiology: Idiopathic; may involve effacement (flattening) of foot processes on the basement membrane. Major cause of nephrotic syndrome
Epidemiology: 10–50 cases per 100,000 children. Slightly more common in Asia and has a male predominance (approximately 2:1) in young children
Signs/Symptoms: HTN, prone to infections; most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children
Diagnostics: Hyperlipidemia, hypoalbuminemia; proteinuria, flattening of basement membrane foot processes seen on electron microscopy
Treatments: Corticosteroids, cytotoxic agents

Pathophysiology:
Idiopathic or associated with drug use or HIV; segmental
sclerosis of glomeruli
Epidemiology:
Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome
in adults in the US.  Most common cause of ESRD in African-American children
Signs/Symptoms: Hypertension, edema, and weight gain.
Diagnostics: Hypoalbuminemia; hematuria and high proteinuria  sclerotic changes seen in some glomeruli on EM
Treatments: Corticosteroids, cytotoxic agents, ACE-I, statins

Pathophysiology: Intercapillary glomerulosclerosis, mesangial expansion, and basement membrane degeneration that develops after chronic DM
Epidemiology: 1/3 of people with type 1 or type 2 DM
Signs/Symptoms: S/s of renal insufficiency (e.g., HTN, uremia)
Diagnostics: Hypoalbuminemia, increased Cr, increased BUN; proteinuria and microalbuminuria; basement membrane thickening and Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules in glomeruli on EM
Treatments: control diabetes; ACE-I or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), low-protein diet, infection prevention; dialysis may eventually be required

Pathophysiology: Deposition of amyloid protein fibrils in tissues
Epidemiology: Incidence of  1.2 per 100,000/year worldwide
Signs/Symptoms: Numbness, tingling, carpal tunnel, glaucoma, heart failure, edema, and renal failure, wasting.
Diagnostics: Hyperlipidemia, hypoalbuminemia, elevated Cr; proteinuria, apple-green birefringence on polarized light
Treatments: Melphalan, hematopoietic stem cell transplant, renal transplant

Pathophysiology: Impaired H1 secretion leading to secondary hyperaldosteronism caused by Idiopathic, autoimmune diseases, drugs, etc
Epidemiology: more in females than males
Signs/Symptoms: Confusion, Impaired growth in children, Increased breathing rate.  Nephrocalcinosis, Osteomalacia, Muscle weakness.
Diagnostics: pH>5.3, Low K1, variable HCO32, stones
Treatments: Oral HCO32, K1, thiazide diuretic

Pathophysiology: HCO32 reabsorption, Causes are idiopathic, multiple myeloma,  Fanconi syndrome, Wilson disease, amyloidosis
Epidemiology: essentially higher risk if having an underlying cause.
Signs/Symptoms: Confusion, Impaired growth in children, Increased breathing rate.  Nephrocalcinosis, Osteomalacia, Muscle weakness.
Diagnostics: pH <5.3, Low K1, low HCO3, bone lesions,
Treatments: Oral HCO32, K1; thiazide or loop diuretic

Pathophysiology: tubular dysfunction causes reduced renal clearance of potassium; a reduced rate of renal bicarbonate reabsorption at normal plasma bicarbonate concentrations
Epidemiology: Caused by Primary or secondary hypoaldosteronism, Cause; Primary renin or aldosterone  deficiency, DM, Addison disease, sickle cell disease, interstitial  disease
Signs/Symptoms: Growth retardation, muscle weakness, dehydration, polyuria
Diagnostics: pH <5.3, High K1, high C
Treatments: Fludrocortisone, K restriction

Pathophysiology: Disorders of ADH-directed water reabsorption leading to dehydration and hypernatremia
Epidemiology: low prevalence of 1 in 25,0000.
Signs/Symptoms: Polydipsia, polyuria, signs of dehydration
Diagnostics: Hypernatremia, Low urine osmolality, CT with contrast or MRI may show pituitary tumor
Treatments: Treat underlying condition, desmopressin (DDAVP), salt restriction, increased H2O intake; thiazide diuretics

Pathophysiology: Nonphysiologic release of ADH caused by CNS pathology, sarcoidosis, paraneoplastic syndromes, psychiatric drugs, etc
Epidemiology: Prevalence 2500-3000/100,000 individuals
Signs/Symptoms: Chronic hyponatremia
Diagnostics:
Serum hypo-osmolarity (<280 mOsm/kg) with urine osmolarity
<100 mOsm/kg; urine Na <20 mEq/L
Treatments: Fluid restriction; loop diuretics, hypertonic saline, demeclocycline

Pathophysiology:
1. Malignant tumor of renal origin presenting 
2. Risk factors 5 family history, neurofibromatosis, other genitourinary abnormalities
Epidemiology: Incidence is 1/10,000 worldwide
Signs/Symptoms:
weight loss, dysuria, polyuria; palpable abdominal or
flank mass, hypertension
Diagnostics:
Measure BUN, Cr, and CBC to assess kidney function
CT/US shows renal mass; CXR and CT can show metastases
Treatments: Nephrectomy, chemotherapy, radiotherapy

Pathophysiology: Testes lying in abdominal cavity and not consistently located within scrotum
Epidemiology: Prevalence is 30% in premature male neonates.
Signs/Symptoms: Empty scrotal sac, testes inconsistently found in scrotum
Diagnostics: Testes not palpable in scrotum, unable to milk down from inquinal canals
Treatments: Exogenous hCG administration or orchiopexy,

Pathophysiology: Abnormal folds of tissue in the distal prostatic urethra, causing bladder outlet obstruction and weak urinary stream
Epidemiology: incidence is 1:5000–1:8000 in males.
Signs/Symptoms: Often diagnosed on prenatal US; weak urinary stream, UTI; abdominal distention
Diagnostics: US reveals thick-walled bladder, bilateral hydronephrosi
Treatments: Cystoscopic transurethral ablation of abnormal tissue or vesicostomy

Pathophysiology: median nerve compression at the wrist, associated with hypothyroidism, obesity, overuse.
Epidemiology:
Pregnancy, RA, DM, acromegaly, overuse, etc
 30 to 55 years of age; female  > male
Signs/Symptoms: Wrist pain that radiates up the arm and worsens with hand flexion and grasping, decreased hand strength, numbness in the thumb and in the index and middle fingers
Diagnostics: Positive Tinel sign and Phalen sign, nerve conduction studies show impaired conduction
Treatments: Wrist splints, activity modification, NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, surgery

Pathophysiology:
Trauma in extremities leads to reperfusion injury and swelling of fascial compartments 
Most common in the lower leg and forearm
Epidemiology: Incidence is 7.3/100,000 in males and 0.7/100,000 in females.
Signs/Symptoms: 6 Ps: Pain, Pallor, Poikilothermia, Pulselessness, Paresthesia, Paralysis,
Diagnostics: Elevated compartment pressures, compartment pain with passive stretching is best screening test
Treatments:
Emergent fasciotomy for pressures > 30 mm Hg or for pressures
within 20 mm Hg of diastolic blood pressure

Pathophysiology: Distal radius with or without distal ulna
Signs/Symptoms: Fall on outstretched hand, distal radius is posteriorly displaced and angulated (forearm profile looks like a dinner fork)
Diagnostics: History, clinical examination, x-ray
Treatments: Closed reduction, Long arm cast, surgery

Pathophysiology: fracture of distal radius
Epidemiology: children with high-energy falls and osteoporotic seniors with low-energy falls.
Signs/Symptoms: Fall on flexed wrists, distal radius is anteriorly displaced.
Diagnostics: History, clinical examination, x-ray
Treatments: Cast, Closed reduction, surgery

Pathophysiology: Fracture of Scaphoid bone
Epidemiology: most common in males 15 to 30 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Snuffbox” tenderness, fall on  radially deviated outstretched hand
Diagnostics: History, clinical examination, x-ray
Treatments: Thumb spica cast. Possible surgery

Pathophysiology: Fracture of Fifth-metacarpal neck
Signs/Symptoms: Punching hard object or surface with a strong force applied to fifth metacarpal
Diagnostics: History, clinical examination, x-ray
Treatments: Closed reduction. Ulnar gutter splint, Surgical pinning

Pathophysiology: Fracture of proximal one-third of ulna with dislocation of radial head
Signs/Symptoms: Fracture of proximal one-third of ulna with dislocation of the radial head, Fall on the outstretched arm with arm hyperpronated
Diagnostics: History, clinical examination, x-ray
Treatments: Closed reduction of the radial head, Surgery

Pathophysiology: Fracture of distal shaft of radius and dislocation of DRUJ
Signs/Symptoms:
Fracture of distal shaft of radius and dislocation of DRUJ
Trauma (direct blow or fall)
Diagnostics: History, examination, x-ray
Treatments: Surgical repair, Cast forearm in supination to maintain reduction of DRUJ

Pathophysiology: Degenerative changes in disc leading to its herniation
Epidemiology: Most common in the lumbosacral region (L4–L5, L5–S1 discs).
Signs/Symptoms: Pain along path of compressed nerve; sensory and motor deficits, the pain worsens with Valsalva maneuver, MRI confirms the diagnosis
Diagnostics: MRI/Ct to confirm diagnosis and to view bones
Treatments: Self-limited; NSAIDs, activity modification, epidural injection, surgical decompression

Pathophysiology: Generalized narrowing of bony spaces in the spine secondary to arthritic changes, causing nerve compression
Epidemiology: Most common in middle-aged and older adults.
Signs/Symptoms: Radiating pain that is worse with standing and walking (“pseudoclaudication”), pain relieved when leaning forward
Diagnostics: CT/X-ray confirms diagnosis; MRI helpful to rule out herniation
Treatments: NSAIDs, physical therapy, epidural injections, surgical decompression

Pathophysiology: nerve roots in the lumbar spine are compressed, cutting off sensation and movement
Signs/Symptoms: Urinary retention, change in bowel habits, saddle anesthesia, decreased bulbocavernosus reflex
Diagnostics: Ct/MRI, Bladder scan,
Treatments: Emergency surgical decompression, IV corticosteroids, radiotherapy for neoplasms

Pathophysiology: Injury to Superior trunk caused by hyper-adduction of arm causing widening of the humeral-glenoid gap.
Epidemiology: macrosomia (large baby) and shoulder dystocia
Signs/Symptoms: Waiter’s tip (arm extended and adducted with pronated forearm)
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination
Treatments: physical therapy, NSAIDs, opioid analgesics

Pathophysiology: Injury to Ulnar nerve caused by Epiphyseal separation of medial epicondyle of humerus
Epidemiology: Men are more likely to acquire the condition than women, but the congenital form of claw hand is distributed evenly among both sexes.
Signs/Symptoms: Weak finger adduction, poor fourth- or fifth finger flexion, clawed fourth or fifth fingers from lumbrical weakness
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination
Treatments: Physical therapy, analgesics

Pathophysiology: Injury to posterior or medial cords due to hyper-abduction of arm places excess tension on lower cords and nearby sympathetic chain
Signs/Symptoms: Claw hand, poor wrist and hand function, association with Horner syndrome
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination
Treatments: Physical therapy, Analgesics

Pathophysiology: Decreased bone density but normal mineralization in existing bone stock
Epidemiology: Risk factors: inadequate dietary calcium, smoking, sedentary lifestyle, decreased estrogen or testosterone, white, postmenopausal women
Signs/Symptoms: Usually asymptomatic until fractures and neurovascular impingement occur
Diagnostics: Decreased bone density evident on DEXA scan, X-ray, and CT
Treatments: Prevention, exercise, calcium and vitamin D in diet, Bisphosphonates,  hormone replacement therapy, Pulsatile teriparatide

Pathophysiology: Overactive osteoclasts and osteoblasts leading to excessive bone turnover and disorganized bony architecture
Epidemiology: Prevalence in US is 1-2 percent of the general population.
Signs/Symptoms: Asymptomatic, deep bone pain, fractures; tibial bowing, kyphosis,  deafness
Diagnostics: Increased ALP and urine hydroxyproline; normal Ca and PO, X-rays show osteolytic lesions and expanded hyperdense bone; “hot spots” on bone scan
Treatments: Bisphosphonates, calcitonin

Pathophysiology: Defective production of collagen from a genetic disorder
Epidemiology: Incidence is 1/20,000 births.
Signs/Symptoms: Frequent fractures from minimal trauma, blue sclerae, skin and dentinogenesis imperfecta,, possible deafness, joint hypermobility
Diagnostics: Diagnosis primarily made during childhood, History and clinical examination
Treatments:
Activity restriction, surgical correction of bony misalignment,
bisphosphonates

Pathophysiology: Peripheral monoarthritis caused by the deposition of sodium urate crystals in joints
Epidemiology: Risk factors: renal disease, male gender, obesity, excessive consumption of purine-rich foods, etc.
Signs/Symptoms: Sudden severe pain and swelling in one joint, first metatarsophalangeal joint commonly affected, chills, or malaise.
Diagnostics: Serum uric acid can be normal or increased; joint aspiration shows needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals
Treatments: NSAIDs, colchicine, corticosteroids, dietery modifications, Allopurinol

Pathophysiology: Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal deposition in joints.
Epidemiology: A familial condition associated with other endocrine diseases.
Signs/Symptoms: Similar to gout but less severe symptoms; knee and wrist most commonly initially affected joints
Diagnostics: Joint aspiration shows positively birefringent, rhomboid crystals, X-ray show chondrocalcinosis
Treatments: NSAIDs, colchicine

Pathophysiology: Hematogenous spread of bacteria, extension of local infection, or direct inoculation into the joints
Signs/Symptoms: Monoarticular joint pain; micromotion tenderness, overlying skin lesions.
Diagnostics: Increased WBCs, ESR and CRP; joint fluid culture show organism
Treatments: I&D for infection, IV antibiotics

Pathophysiology: Bone infection via hematogenous spread or local extension
Epidemiology: Incidence is 13/100,000 in children and 90/100,000 in adults.
Signs/Symptoms: Bone pain, tenderness, fever, chills; possible skin involvement with a draining sinus
Diagnostics: Increased WBC, ESR, and CRP; cultures, MRI demonstrates bone edema early in disease; bone scan shows increased uptake after 72 hrs
Treatments: IV antibiotics, I&D

Pathophysiology: Chronic autoimmune inflammatory disorder with infiltration of synovial joints by inflammatory cells
Epidemiology: Common in middle-aged women; increased frequency in people with HLA-DR4 serotype.
Signs/Symptoms: Malaise, weight loss, insidious onset of morning stiffness with pain, decreased mobility, MCP hypertrophy, swan-neck deformities,  boutonniere deformities
Diagnostics: RF positive, positive ACPA and ANA, joint aspiration shows 5,000 to 50,000 leukocytes, X-rays shows soft tissue swellings, joint space narrowing, etc.
Treatments: DMARDs, HCQ or sulfasalazine, Methotrexate or TNF-α inhibitors, Glucocorticoids and NSAIDs

Pathophysiology: Chronic pain in muscles and tendons in absence of apparent inflammation frequently associated with depression, anxiety, and IBD
Epidemiology: Predisposition with hypothyroidism, RA, sleep apnea; more common in women 20 to 50 years of age.
Signs/Symptoms: Myalgias and weakness without inflammation; “trigger points” on examination, depression, sleep disturbances, dizziness, mood disturbances
Diagnostics: widespread pain involving both sides of the body, above and below the waist as well as the axial skeletal system, for at least three months; and presence of 11 tender points among specified sites
Treatments: Stretching, antidepressants, patient education, physical therapy

Pathophysiology: Chronic inflammatory disease of the spine and pelvis that results in eventual bone fusion
Epidemiology: Risk factors: 20 to 40 years of age, male > female, white > black.
Signs/Symptoms: Hip and low back pain that is worse in the morning which improves on activity, limited range of motion in spine, hip, or chest, Painful kyphosis
Diagnostics: Positive HLA-B27, increased or normal ESR, negative RF, negative ANA, X-ray shows bamboo spine
Treatments: Physical therapy, NSAIDs; exercise, sulfasalazine, methotrexate, or anti-TNF drugs

Pathophysiology: Arthritis that develops in 10% to 20% of patients with psoriasis; DIP joints and spine most commonly affected
Epidemiology: white males between 15 and 40, most common spondyloarthropathy.
Signs/Symptoms:
Asymmetric joint pain and stiffness, symptoms worse in morning and
improve with activity
Diagnostics: Negative RF and ANA, positive HLA-B27, X-rays show findings similar to RA and “pencil in cup” deformities
Treatments: NSAIDs, methotrexate, sulfasalazine, anti-TNF drugs

Pathophysiology: Most common primary malignant bone tumor.
Epidemiology: Male>female, Risk factors: Paget disease of bone, p53 genetic mutations, familial retinoblastoma, etc.
Signs/Symptoms: Deep bony pain, later development of palpable bony mass.
Diagnostics: Increased ALP, ESR and LDH; biopsy for definitive diagnosis, X-ray shows  sunburst pattern and Codman triangle MRI/PET scan for determining extent of the lesion
Treatments: Radical surgical excision, chemotherapy

Pathophysiology: Highly malignant cartilage tumor occurring in diaphysis of long bones; most common in children, 5 to 15 years of age
Epidemiology: 2.93/1,000,000,most common in children, 5 to 15 years of age.
Signs/Symptoms: Bony pain, tissue swelling, weight loss, fractures with minor trauma; possible palpable mass
Diagnostics: Increased WBCs and ESR, decreased Hgb, biopsy for making diagnosis, X-ray show Codman triangle, or “onion-skin” bone lesion),
Treatments: Radiation, adjuvant chemotherapy, radical excision

Pathophysiology: Perinatal displacement of the femoral head from acetabulum disrupting normal development of the hip joint
Epidemiology: Risk factors: female > male, firstborn children, babies delivered in breech presentation, oligohydramnios.
Signs/Symptoms: Delayed walking, abnormal gait, Positive Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers, Trendelenburg gait
Diagnostics: US imaging show hip congruity
Treatments: Pavlik harness used in children, closed or open reduction, Spica casting, open reduction

Pathophysiology: Separation through growth plate of femoral epiphysis from metaphysis
Epidemiology: Risk factors: adolescent, obese, black race, hypothyroidism.
Signs/Symptoms: Thigh and knee pain; limp, limited internal rotation and abduction of the hip
Diagnostics:
X-rays shows posterior and medial displacement of the femoral
head from the femoral metaphysis
Treatments: Surgical pinning, weight-bearing restrictions

Pathophysiology: AVN of capital femoral epiphysis
Epidemiology: Most common between 3 and 8 years of age.
Signs/Symptoms: Gradual progressive limp, insidious onset of pain, decreased range of motion
Diagnostics:
X-ray shows asymmetric hips; affected femoral head appears small
with sclerotic bone and widened joint space
Treatments: Containment of hip, acetabular reconstruction

Pathophysiology: Inflammation of the bone–cartilage interface of the tibial tubercle (i.e., osteochondritis)
Epidemiology: Most common in young boys during pubertal growth spurt
Signs/Symptoms: Pain at an involved site that worsens with activity
Diagnostics: Clinical examination, X-ray,
Treatments: Stretching exercises, NSAIDs, tibial band

Pathophysiology: Inversion of foot, plantar flexion of ankle, and adduction of forefoot
Epidemiology: Prevalence is  0.6 and 1.5 per 1000 live births
Signs/Symptoms: Child who is slow to walk, limp; obvious defect on examination
Diagnostics: Clinical examination,
Treatments: Serial casting of foot in correct position; surgery if required

Pathophysiology: Radial head subluxation that occurs via pulling and lifting on the hand
Epidemiology: ~2.5yo, females>males, left arm more common
Signs/Symptoms: Child with painful arm who will not bend elbow
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination, MRI to check ligament integrity
Treatments:
Manual reduction via supination of the arm with flexion of the elbow
from 0° to 90° of flexion

Pathophysiology: Impaired calcification of bone in children caused by deficient vitamin D intake, absorption, or metabolism or impaired phosphate absorption
Epidemiology: Incidence of less than 1 in 200,000
Signs/Symptoms: Bone pain, delayed walking; bowed legs, kyphoscoliosis, decreased height, softened skull bones; fractures that result from minimal trauma
Diagnostics: Increased ALP decreased PO, Ca, increased 25-hydroxyvitamin D3, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, increased PTH, X-rays demonstrate bone deformities
Treatments: Phosphorus supplementation, vitamin D supplementation

Pathophysiology: Nonmigratory arthropathy affecting one or more joints for .3 months
Epidemiology: Prevalence of 16-50 cases/100,000
Signs/Symptoms: Arthralgias, morning stiffness; fever
Diagnostics: vary with subtype, X-rays  demonstrate osteopenia and subchondral sclerosis around involved joints
Treatments: Varies with subtype, NSAIDs, methotrexate, or corticosteroids

Pathophysiology: X-linked disorder resulting from deficiency of dystrophin
Epidemiology: Prevalence is 1 in every 3,500 live male births. Onset at 2 to 6 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Clumsiness, easy fatigability, difficulty standing up and walking, waddling gait, positive Gower maneuver, pseudohypertrophy
Diagnostics:
Increased CK, immunostaining for dystrophin is diagnostic,
EMG: polyphasic potentials and increased fiber recruitment
Treatments:
Physical therapy, corticosteroids, pulmonary support, ACE-I decrease
cardiac afterload

Pathophysiology: Involuntary leakage of urine
Epidemiology: more common in the elderly
Signs/Symptoms: History of urgency, frequent voiding of small amounts of urine, and possibly incontinence
Diagnostics: History, Urinalysis show UTI or blood sugar, bladder stress test, US or CT show bladder defects
Treatments:
Bladder training, antimuscarinics (oxybutynin, tolterodine,
solifenacin, etc.)

Pathophysiology: Leakage of urine during any maneuver that increases abdominal pressure due to decreased anatomic support of and function of the urinary sphincter
Epidemiology: Risk factors: female, sex, multiparity, obesity.
Signs/Symptoms: incontinence accompanies coughing, sneezing, laughing, exercise, lifting heavy objects
Diagnostics: Urinanalysis, Nerve test, urinary stress test,
Treatments: Conservative therapy (weight loss, Kegel exercises), surgical therapy (midurethral sling)

Pathophysiology: Leakage of urine due to uninhibited bladder contractions
Epidemiology: 51% of adult women in the United States
Signs/Symptoms: Signs of infection, urinary incontinence
Diagnostics: History of urgency, frequent voiding of small amounts of urine, and possibly incontinence
Treatments:
Bladder training, antimuscarinics (oxybutynin, tolterodine,
solifenacin, etc.)

Pathophysiology: Infection of urethra caused by sexually transmitted Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis
Epidemiology: 4 million Americans each year are affected.
Signs/Symptoms: Dysuria,urgency, burning urination; purulent urethral discharge seen with N. gonorrhoeae
Diagnostics: Gram stain shows the type of infection, diagnosis of Chlamydia may be confirmed with nucleic acid amplification testing
Treatments: Single-dose ceftriaxone with doxycycline or azithromycin

Pathophysiology: Inflammation of prostate from unknown cause or as complication of UTI
Epidemiology: 8 percent of visits to urologists, and up to 1 percent of visits to primary care physicians
Signs/Symptoms: Perineal pain, dysuria, tender prostate on digital rectal examination
Diagnostics: Incidence of UTI; hematuria; white blood cells seen in prostatic secretions
Treatments: TMP-SMX,  treat for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) in sexually active males

Pathophysiology: Benign enlargement of prostate
Epidemiology: Increasing frequency as men age beyond 40 years
Signs/Symptoms:
urinary hesitancy, straining, weak or intermittent stream, dribbling;
frequency, urgency, nocturia,
Diagnostics: Increase in PSA; rule out infection (urinalysis), cancer (biopsy), and renal failure (serum electrolytes, BUN, Cr), the transrectal US shows an enlarged prostate
Treatments: a1-receptor blockers, a-reductase inhibitors, surgery

Pathophysiology: Adenocarcinoma occurring in peripheral zone of prostate
Epidemiology:
Most common cancer diagnosis made in men
Risk factors: increased age, family history, high-fat diet, prostatitis.
Signs/Symptoms: Asymptomatic; weakened urinary stream, urinary retention, nodular or irregular prostate on digital examination, lymphedema
Diagnostics: Hematuria and pyuria; increased PSA, increased  ALP, transrectal US shows irregular prostate; bone scan, CXR, and CT to detect metastases
Treatments: Radical retropubic, perineal, laparoscopic, or robotic prostatectomy; radiotherapy, Antiandrogen therapy.

Pathophysiology: Inflammation of epididymis associated with testicular inflammation
Epidemiology: 1 in 1000 men annually in US.
Signs/Symptoms: Epididymal pain relieved by supporting scrotum, dysuria; scrotal tenderness, and induration
Diagnostics: Urinalysis shows white blood cells; urine culture with specialized culture media to diagnose STDs
Treatments:
Ceftriaxone, doxycycline or fluoroquinolone; NSAIDs and scrotal
support for noninfectious causes

Pathophysiology: Twisting of spermatic cord leading to vascular insufficiency of testes
Epidemiology: bimodal, with one peak in the neonatal period and the second peak around puberty.
Signs/Symptoms: Very painful and swollen testes, testes displaced superiorly, absent cremasteric reflex, US may show torsion
Diagnostics: History and physical exam, US
Treatments: Emergent surgical reduction of torsion, manual detorsion

Pathophysiology: Germ cell (seminomatous, nonseminomatous) or stromal cell (Leydig, Sertoli, or granulosa cell) tumors of testicles
Epidemiology: Risk factors: prior history of testicular cancer, undescended testes, family history.
Signs/Symptoms: Painless testicular mass, gynecomastia; GI or pulmonary symptoms can result from metastases
Diagnostics:
Increased b-hCG and a-fetoprotein, estrogen in stromal cell tumors
US may detect dense testicular mass; CXR/CT can detect extent
Treatments: Radical orchiectomy with/without chemotherapy and radiation therapy

Pathophysiology: autoimmune destruction of b-islet cells, HLA-DR3, HLA-DR4, and HLA-DQ
Epidemiology: Bimodal age distribution (first peak at 4 to 6 years, second peak at 10 to 14 years)
Signs/Symptoms: Polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, weight loss; more rapid onset than type II DM
Diagnostics: hyperglycemia, glycosuria, serum and urine ketones, increased HbA1c
Treatments: insulin injections or continuous insulin infusion via insulin pump

Pathophysiology: resistance to insulin, hyperglycemia
Epidemiology: > 40 years; obesity, metabolic syndrome
Signs/Symptoms: Asymptomatic in early stages, eventual polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, acanthosis nigricans
Diagnostics: HbA1c
Treatments: nutrition, Metforin, possibly insulin

Pathophysiology: Extremely low insulin and glucagon excess causing degradation of triglycerides into fatty acids and eventual conversion into keto acids
Epidemiology: uncontrolled DM type I, often how new patients present
Signs/Symptoms: fruity odor on breath, hyperventilation (Kussmaul respiration), delirium
Diagnostics: Glucose 300 to 800 mg/dL (rarely .1,000) an-ion gap metabolic acidosis, serum and urine ketones
Treatments: Treat underlying disorder, IV fluids, insulin, KCl

Pathophysiology: hepatic glucose production through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, leading to hyperglycemia, intracellular water depletion, and subsequent osmotic diuresis.
Epidemiology: more common in the African-American male population as compared to the Caucasian population.
Signs/Symptoms: Polyuria, polydipsia, dehydration, mental status changes; seizures and stroke in severe cases
Diagnostics: Glucose > 800 no acidosis
Treatments: IV fluids, insulin, correction of electrolyte abnormalities; treat underlying  disorder

Pathophysiology: Autoimmune TSI antibodies bind to TSH receptors and stimulate thyroid hormone production
Epidemiology: 16 cases/100,000 women and 3 cases/100,000 men; between 30 and 60 years
Signs/Symptoms: Exophthalmos, pretibial myxedema, painless goiter
Diagnostics: Increased T4 and T3, decreased TSH, high uptake on thyroid scan
Treatments: Thionamides (methimazole, PTU), radioablation with radioactive iodine or subtotalthyroidectomy for definitive cure; atenolol for symptomatic relief

Pathophysiology: Most common cause of hyperthyroidism; antithyroid antibodies against the thyroid tissue, causing progressive fibrosis
Epidemiology: Autoimmune condition characterized by chronic thyroiditis; most commonly in middle-aged women
Signs/Symptoms: Fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, irregular menstruation, depression, hoarseness; hyporeflexia, bradycardia, dry skin, edema, painless goiter
Diagnostics:
Increased TSH, decreased total T4, decreased free T4, antithyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO and antithyroglobulin antibodies; lymphocytic infiltrates and fibrosis on biopsy
Radiology: decreased uptake on thyroid scan (i.e., “cold scan”),
Treatments: Lifelong levothyroxine replacement

Pathophysiology: Excess secretion of GH by anterior pituitary caused by adenoma
Epidemiology: In a population of 1 million, 60 to 70 adults have acromegaly, and about three new cases are detected each year.
Signs/Symptoms: Large hands and feet, coarsening of facial features,  thickened skin, increased body hair growth, joint pain, neuralgia, enlarged kidneys
Diagnostics: Increased GH, increased GH 1 to 2 hr following 100 g glucose load,  Radiology: CT/MRI may detect tumor, X-rays: increased bone density
Treatments: Surgical resection of adenoma, dopamine agonists/octreotide to lessen effects of GH; radiation therapy in non-responsive cases

Pathophysiology: Non-physiologic release of ADH, resulting in hyponatremia secondary to other pathologies
Signs/Symptoms: Chronic hyponatremia
Diagnostics: Serum hypo-osmolarity (280 mOsm/kg) with urine osmolarity 100 mOsm/kg
Treatments: Fluid restriction, loop diuretics, hypertonic saline if symptomatic,  demeclocycline to maintain normal Na levels

Pathophysiology: Primary hyperaldosteronism due to an adrenal adenoma
Epidemiology: Twice as common in women as in men, high incidence between 30-50 years
Signs/Symptoms: Headache, weakness, paresthesias; recalcitrant HTN, tetany
Diagnostics: Decreased K, metabolic alkalosis, mildly hypernatremia, decreased renin, increased 24-hr urine aldosterone
Treatments: Surgical resection of tumor (primary hyperaldosteronism),  aldosterone antagonists (e.g., spironolactone)

Pathophysiology: Deficiency of adrenal hormones cortisol and aldosterone resulting in kidney damage
Epidemiology: Approximately 1 in 100,000 people in United States
Signs/Symptoms: Extreme fatigue. weight loss, decreased appetite, hyperpigmentation, low blood pressure, salt craving. hypoglycemia, abdominal pain
Diagnostics: Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, low cortisol, insulin-induced hypoglycemia, eosinophilia, lymphocytosis
Treatments: Oralhormones (Glucocorticoids & mineralocorticoids), good nutrition, regular meals, high carbohydrates, adequate salt

Pathophysiology: Enzymatic defect in the synthesis of cortisol
Epidemiology: 1:15,000 births worldwide
Signs/Symptoms:
17-a-Hydroxylase deficiency: Amenorrhea (women), ambiguous genitalia (men); HTN

21-a-Hydroxylase deficiency: ambiguous genitalia (female infants), virilization (women), macrogenitosomia and precocious puberty (men)

11-b-Hydroxylase deficiency: ambiguous genitalia (female infants), virilization (women), macrogenitosomia and precocious puberty (men); HTN
Diagnostics:
17-a-Hydroxylase deficiency: Decreased K1, increased Na1, decreased androgens and 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone

21-a-Hydroxylase deficiency: Decreased Na1, increased K1 and androgens

11-b-Hydroxylase deficiency: Increased deoxycorticosterone, deoxycortisol and androgens
Treatments:
17-a-Hydroxylase deficiency: cortisol replacement  

21-a-Hydroxylase deficiency: cortisol replacement therapy, fludrocortisone for mineralocorticoid replacement

11-b-Hydroxylase deficiency: cortisol replacement (hydrocortisone/dexamethasone), anti-HTN

Pathophysiology: A tumor that secretes epinephrine and norepinephrine
Epidemiology: 0.66 cases per 100 000 people per year, more prevalent in the elderly (60-79 years)
Signs/Symptoms: palpitations, chest pain, diaphoresis, headache, anxiety; intermittent tachycardia, HTN
Diagnostics: Increased 24-hr urinary catecholamines and metanephrines; increased plasma-free metanephrines; increased 24-hr urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA)
Treatments: Surgical resection; a-and b-blockers used to control blood pressure;
