Pathophysiology: Hereditary disorder of thyroid hormone synthesis that leads to abnormal mental development and growth retardation (deficiency of Iodine)
Epidemiology: 1: 3,000 births. Girls are twice as often affected as boys.
Signs/Symptoms: Poor feeding, lethargy, large fontanelles that remain open, thick tongue, umbilical hernia, growth retardation, dry skin, jaundice
Diagnostics: Decreased T4, increased TSH, Radiology:  poor bone development; thyroid scan: decreased uptake with malformed thyroids and increased uptake with iodide deficiency
Treatments: Levothyroxine started soon after birth to avoid permanent developmental delays

Pathophysiology: rotavirus, norovirus, adenovirus, and astroviruses account for most cases. Most are transmitted via the fecal-oral route, including contaminated food and water.
Epidemiology: The most frequent cause of diarrheal disease worldwide. Men and women are affected equally. Norovirus is the most common viral cause
Signs/Symptoms: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, myalgias; low-grade fever
Diagnostics: Medical history, No fecal white blood cells; viral culture indicates pathogen
Treatments: Self-limited (48 to 72 hours); maintain hydration status in developed countries. Can have significant mortality in underdeveloped countries and in children.

Pathophysiology: Variety of bacteria that can cause cytotoxin production and invasion and destruction of intestinal mucosal cells >> leads to diarrhea
Epidemiology: Travelers diarrhea (50% of travelers), 9:1000 cases in pediatrics lead to hospitalizaiton
Signs/Symptoms: Fever, diarrhea (watery or bloody), abdominal cramping, and pain
Diagnostics: Medical history and examination, stool culture will specify bacteria, electrolyte imbalance
Treatments:
Rehydration, antibiotics, supportive therapy
Avoid antibiotics in bloody stools due to increase in toxin release!

Pathophysiology: Neuromuscular disorder of esophagus with impaired peristalsis and decreased LES relaxation because of intramural neuron dysfunction
Epidemiology: Idiopathic; most commonly affects persons 25 to 60 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Dysphagia of solids and liquids, regurgitation, cough, aspiration, heartburn
Diagnostics: Manometry shows increased LES pressure, incomplete LES relaxation, and decreased peristalsis, Barium swallow shows “bird’s beak” sign
Treatments: Nitrates and calcium channel blockers relax LES, pneumatic dilation, botulinum injections, myotomy relieve obstruction

Pathophysiology: Low pressure in LES leads to abnormal reflux of gastric contents into esophagus.
Epidemiology: Prevalence is 18.1% to 27.8% in the US, Risk factors: obesity, hiatal hernia, pregnancy, scleroderma
Signs/Symptoms: “heartburn” 30 to 90 min after eating, sour taste in mouth, regurgitation, dysphagia, odynophagia
Diagnostics: Esophageal pH monitoring can detect increased acidity, EGD, CXR or barium swallow can help rule out other conditions
Treatments: Supportive therapy, H2 antagonists, PPIs, surgery

Pathophysiology: Squamous cell carcinoma or adenocarcinoma of esophagus
Epidemiology: Risk factors: alcohol, tobacco, chronic GERD, obesity
Signs/Symptoms: progressive dysphagia, weight loss, odynophagia, reflux, GI bleeding, vomiting, weakness, hoarseness
Diagnostics: Biopsy, barium swallow shows narrowing of esophagus and abnormal mass, MRI/CT/PET scan to detect extension and metastases
Treatments: Surgical resection, radiation and chemotherapy

Pathophysiology: Herniation of part of stomach above diaphragm. caused by increased intra-abdominal pressure, which leads to the protrusion of the stomach and other abdominal viscera into the mediastinum
Epidemiology: overweight, multiple pregnancies, history of esophageal surgery, partial or full gastrectomy
Signs/Symptoms: Asymptomatic; symptoms associated with GERD; CXR detect hernia without barium swallow
Diagnostics:
CXR, baarium swallow, endoscopy
Dx includes classification into one of four types (see link)
Treatments:
Sliding hernias treated with reflux control; paraesophageal
hernias need surgical repair

Pathophysiology: Inflammation of gastric mucosa
Epidemiology: 6.3 per 100,000 individuals worldwide
Signs/Symptoms: Asymptomatic; epigastric pain, indigestion, hematemesis, melena;
Diagnostics: positive urea breath test, positive IgG antibody to H.pylori, antral biopsy can detect H. pylori infection
Treatments:
Treat the cause, H2 antagonists or PPI, vitamin B12 replacement.
antibiotics

Pathophysiology: Erosion of gastric and duodenal mucosa secondary to impaired endothelial defenses and increased gastric acidity
Epidemiology: Risk factors: H. pylori infection, NSAID use, tobacco, alcohol, corticosteroids; males > females
Signs/Symptoms: periodic burning, epigastric pain, hematemesis, melena, hematochezia; epigastric tenderness;
Diagnostics: Positive urea breath test, IgG antibodies or H. pylori; CBC for GI bleeding, AXR to detect perforation, barium swallow AXR can demonstrate collections of barium in ulcerations;
Treatments: Treat the cause, PPI and H2 antagonist; sucralfate, bismuth subsalicylate, or misoprostol;antibiotics, surgery.

Pathophysiology: Syndrome secondary to gastrin-producing tumor most frequently located in duodenum (70% cases) or pancreas
Epidemiology: Incidence is 0.5 to 2 per million population
Signs/Symptoms: Refractory PUD, indigestion, diarrhea, steatorrhea, history of other endocrine abnormalities
Diagnostics: Increased fasting gastrin; positive secretin-stimulation test;  SPECT can localize tumors; angiography
Treatments: Surgical resection, PPI and H2 antagonists, octreotide

Pathophysiology: Genetic disorder characterized by gluten intolerance (e.g., wheat, barley, rye)
Epidemiology: Prevalence estimates range from 1:80 in US
Signs/Symptoms: Bloating, abnormal stools in infants; steatorrhea, weight loss, depression, arthralgias
Diagnostics:
Positive antiendomysial and antigliadin antibodies in serum; biopsy
shows blunting of duodenal and jejunal villi
Treatments: Gluten-freen diet,  corticosteroids

Pathophysiology: Continuous disease beginning at rectum and extending possibly as far as distal ileum; only mucosa and sub-mucosa affected
Epidemiology: incidence of 9 to 20 cases per 100,000 per year
Signs/Symptoms: Abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, tenesmus, orthostatic hypotension, gross blood on rectal examination, Arthritis, uveitis, ankylosing spondylitis, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum
Diagnostics: pANCA positive; biopsy diagnostic, Colonoscopy shows continuous  involvement, pseudopolyps, friable mucosa; barium enema shows “lead pipe” colon
Treatments: Mesalamine, supplemental iron, corticosteroids, immunosuppressives; total colectomy

Pathophysiology: Inflammation of the appendix with infection or perforation
Epidemiology: 5 and 45, with a mean age of 28, lifetime incidence of 8.6% and 6.7% for men, and women respectively
Signs/Symptoms: Dull periumbilical pain, rebound tenderness, psoas sign, Rovsing sign  perforation produces severe pain
Diagnostics: Increased WBC,  CT most sensitive test and may show bowel wall thickening, appendicolith, abscess, phlegmon
Treatments: Appendectomy; antibiotics added for ruptured appendix

Pathophysiology:
Paralytic obstruction of bowel secondary to decreased peristalsis
caused by infection, ischemia, recent surgery, DM, opioid use
Epidemiology: most common s/p intra-abdominal surgery, other causes include inflammatory (appendicitis, diverticulitis etc), hypokalemia, certain drugs (opioids).
Signs/Symptoms: Vague abdominal pain, no bowel movements, inability to tolerate meals; decreased bowel sounds
Diagnostics: AXR shows distention of affected bowel, air-fluid levels; barium enema to rule out obstruction
Treatments: Treat the cause, make patient NPO, colonoscopic decompression

Pathophysiology: Rotation of bowel creates obstruction and possible ischemia
Epidemiology: Tends to occur in elderly and infants
Signs/Symptoms: Distention, abdominal pain, obstipation; AXR show “double bubble” proximal and distal to volvulus; barium enema shows “bird’s beak”
Diagnostics: AXR, barium enema
Treatments: Self-limited; colonoscopic decompression of sigmoid volvulus; surgical repair

Pathophysiology: Inflammation of gallbladder commonly caused by gallstone obstruction of cystic duct
Epidemiology: increases in women, obese patients, pregnant women, and patients in their 40s. Drastic weight loss or acute illnesses may also increase the risk
Signs/Symptoms:
RUQ tenderness and pain radiating to back, anorexia; palpable
gallbladder
Diagnostics: Increased WBC; increased bilirubin, increased ALP, US show gallstones, sonographic Murphy sign
Treatments: Hydration, antibiotics, cholecystectomy, surgery

Pathophysiology: Progressive destruction of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts leading to fibrosis and cirrhosis
Epidemiology: Risk factors: ulcerative colitis; male > female
Signs/Symptoms:
Asymptomatic; fatigue, pruritus, RUQ pain; fever, night sweats,
jaundice, xanthomas
Diagnostics: Increased ALP, GGT, cholesterol normal AST and ALT, positive pANCA; ERCP shows “beads on string" appearance
Treatments: Endoscopic stenting of strictures; surgical resection, liver transplant

Pathophysiology: Increase in portal vein pressure giving it higher pressure than the inferior vena cava; may result from prehepatic, intrahepatic, or posthepatic causes
Signs/Symptoms: Ascites, abdominal pain, hepatic encephalopathy, hematemesis, abdominal wall varices, testicular atrophy, gynecomastia
Diagnostics: Paracentesis shows ascites with SAAG >1.1, CT may show ascites and obstructing mass; EGD may show esophageal varices
Treatments: Salt restriction and diuretics, IV antibiotics for bacterial peritonitis, Dialysis for renal failure, hepatic shunting, liver transplant

Pathophysiology: An autosomal recessive disease characterized by excess iron absorption causing iron deposition in the liver, pancreas, heart, and pituitary
Epidemiology: Prevalence is 1 in 300-500 individuals
Signs/Symptoms:
Polydipsia, polyuria, arthralgias, impotence, lethargy;
pigmented rash, hepatomegaly
Diagnostics: Increased iron, ferritin, transferrin saturation, AST and ALT; biopsy shows increased iron content in liver
Treatments: Phlebotomy until normal iron, deferoxamine for iron chelation

Pathophysiology: Autosomal recessive disorder of impaired copper secretion, primarily in young adults, Excess copper deposits in liver, brain, cornea
Epidemiology: Prevalence of 1 per 30,000 live births
Signs/Symptoms: Depression, neurosis, loss of coordination, dysphagia, tremor, Kayser-Fleischer rings, hepatomegaly;
Diagnostics: Decreased serum ceruloplasmin, increased urinary copper, AST and ALT; copper deposits in liver on biopsy
Treatments: Trientine or penicillamine, lifelong zinc, vitamin B6; liver transplantation

Pathophysiology: Co-dominant disorder with decreased a1-antitrypsin production leading to cirrhosis and panlobular emphysema
Epidemiology: Family History of AAT, males greater than females, often presents in early 30's with pulmonary symptoms, worse in smokers.
Signs/Symptoms: Emphysema, chronic bronchitis, chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, skin panniculitis
Diagnostics: Increased AST and ALT; PFTs demonstrate obstructive disease
Treatments: Liver transplant or lung transplant, enzyme replacement

Pathophysiology: Hypertrophy of pyloric sphincter causing obstruction of gastric outlet
Epidemiology: Incidence is 2-4 per 1000 live births
Signs/Symptoms: Symptoms begin a few weeks after birth; nonbilious emesis, projectile emesis; palpable epigastric olive-sized mass
Diagnostics:
Hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis
barium swallow shows string sign
Treatments: Pyloromyotomy

Pathophysiology: Idiopathic mucosal necrosis and epithelial cell sloughing
Epidemiology: Risk factors: preterm birth, low birth weight
Signs/Symptoms: bilious vomiting, lethargy, poor feeding, diarrhoea, hematochezia; abdominal distention
Diagnostics: metabolic acidosis, decreased Na, AXR shows bowel distention, air in bowel wall
Treatments: TPN, IV antibiotics, antibiotics, nasogastric suction, surgical resection

Pathophysiology: Absence of bowel autonomic innervation causing bowel spasm and obstruction
Epidemiology: 1/5,000 births
Signs/Symptoms: vomiting, obstipation, failure to pass stool; abdominal distention
Diagnostics: Bowel biopsy shows absence of ganglia, AXR demonstrates dilated bowel; barium enema shows proximal dilation with distal narrowing
Treatments: Colostomy and resection of affected area

Pathophysiology: Telescoping of bowel into adjacent segment of bowel, leading to obstruction
Epidemiology: Risk factors: Meckel diverticulum, Henoch-Schönlein purpura, adenovirus infection, cystic fibrosis
Signs/Symptoms: sudden abdominal pain that lasts ,1 min and is episodic; pallor, sweating, vomiting, bloody mucus in stool (i.e., currant jelly stool); abdominal tenderness; palpable, sausage-like abdominal mass
Diagnostics: Increased WBC, barium enema will show obstruction; US/CT may detect abnormal bowel
Treatments: Barium enema may reduce defect; surgery if required

Pathophysiology: Common remnant of vitelline duct that exists as outpouching of ileum and may contain ectopic tissue
Epidemiology: About 2% of the population. Prevalence in males is 3–5 times higher than in females.
Signs/Symptoms:
Asymptomatic; occasionally presents with painless rectal bleeding,
intussusception, diverticulitis, or abscess formation
Diagnostics: Gastric mucosa may be detected by technetium radionucleotide scan (i.e., Meckel scan)
Treatments: Surgical resection if symptomatic

Pathophysiology: high LDL, low HDL, increased risk of ischemia due to diet, can be genetic
Epidemiology: men > 35, women >45
Signs/Symptoms: asymptomatic, xanthelasmas, emboli in retina
Diagnostics: total cholesterol > 300; elevated LDL, decreased HDL
Treatments: low fat, low cholesterol diet, statin therapy

Pathophysiology: gradual narrowing of arteries and plaque formation
Epidemiology: >50% of people over 40, risk increases with age.
Signs/Symptoms: angina, hypertension, strokes
Diagnostics: stress testing, echocardiogram, angiography of coronaries
Treatments: decrease risk factors, (hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, hyperglycemia tx)

Pathophysiology: chest pain during exertion
Epidemiology: males > females, associated with coronary artery disease
Signs/Symptoms: substernal radiating chest pain during exertion
Diagnostics: cardiac stress test
Treatments: sublingual nitroglycerin

Pathophysiology: angina that occurs with rest, typically plaque rupture or thrombosis in coronary arteries
Epidemiology: Men > Women, typically increases with age, hx of stable angina that is now progressively worsening
Signs/Symptoms: increasing frequency of angina, and symptomatic when at rest.
Diagnostics: ECG shows T wave flattening and ST depression,
Treatments: Morphine, O2, Nitroglycerin, ASA, B-Blockers

Pathophysiology: coronary vessels occlude which causes ischemia and death of cardiac tissue
Epidemiology: Men > Women, higher risk if having HTN, DM, or family history. Postmenopausal females higher risk.
Signs/Symptoms: "elephant on chest" pain, diaphoresis, shortness of breath
Diagnostics:
ST elevation, T wave changes, LBBB on ECG
Serial Cardiac Enzymes
Treatments: Morphine, O2, ASA, Nitroglycerin, Heparin, B-Blocker, Statin, and anti-platelet therapy like clopidogrel

Pathophysiology: AV nodal reentry phenomena causing tachycardia (>100)
Epidemiology: typically young, healthy patients
Signs/Symptoms: sudden tachycardia, can cause SOB, Diaphoresis, syncope
Diagnostics: ECG: >100 BPM, normal QRS, P-waves can be hidden in T waves
Treatments: Valsalva, IV Adenosine, possibly calcium channel blocker, or cardioversion

Pathophysiology: multiple ectopic foci throughout the atria discharging electrical impulses
Epidemiology: Predominately male, older patients, relatively rare
Signs/Symptoms: asymptomatic mostly
Diagnostics: ECG: a variety of shaped P waves with tachycardia
Treatments: Ca Channel or B-Blockers, catheter ablation

Pathophysiology: loss of coordination of atrial contractions
Epidemiology: elderly predominance, comorbidities: HTN, CAD, Rheumatic heart disease, alcohol use
Signs/Symptoms: irregularly irregular pulse, often asymptomatic
Diagnostics: ECG: irregular rate, no discernible P waves
Treatments: Rate Control: Ca-Blockers, and Anticoagulation

Pathophysiology: Rapid firing of an ectopic focus in the atria
Epidemiology: Incidence rates ranged from 5/100,000 in those <50 years old to 587/100,000 in subjects older than 80
Signs/Symptoms:
Palpitations, syncope
Risk Factors: Congestive heart failure (CHF), COPD, valvular disease, pericarditis
Diagnostics: Regular tachycardia>150 bpm, sawtooth pattern of P waves
Treatments: Calcium channel blockers, b-blockers;

Pathophysiology: Ectopic beats from a ventricular origin
Epidemiology: Incidence varies between 100 to 400 per 100,000 individuals worldwide
Signs/Symptoms: Palpitations, syncope
Diagnostics: ECG: early and wide QRS without preceding P wave
Treatments: None if patient is healthy; b-blockers in patients with CAD

Pathophysiology:
Series of 31 PVCs with HR 160 to 240 bpm
Risk factors: CAD, history of MI
Epidemiology: 3% in men and 2% in women with no cardiovascular disease.
Signs/Symptoms: Palpitations, syncope, hypotension
Diagnostics: Series of regular, wide QRS complexes independent of P waves
Treatments: Electrical cardioversion, for recurrent Vtach, internal defibrillator

Pathophysiology: Lack of ordered ventricular contraction leads,
Epidemiology: Risk factors: CAD, MI
Signs/Symptoms: Syncope, hypotension, pulselessness
Diagnostics: ECG: Totally erratic tracing; no P waves or QRS
Treatments: CPR, immediate electric cardioversion

Pathophysiology: The heart muscle doesn't pump blood affectively, Risk factors5 CAD, HTN, COPD, drug toxicity, alcohol use
Epidemiology: 1 to 2% in middle-aged and older adults, reaches 2 to 3% in patients older than age 65 years
Signs/Symptoms: Orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, jugular vein distention (JVD), rales, peripheral edema,
Diagnostics: Increased IBNP and N-terminal pro-BNP , Radiology: chest X-ray (CXR) shows Cardiomegally, Kerley B lines, ECG: ischemic disease, possible LVH
Treatments: Treat the underlying cause, Loop diuretics and ACE-I, calcium channel blocker

Pathophysiology: Acute inflammation of the pericardial sac accompanied by pericardial effusion
Epidemiology: Incidence approximately 27.7 per 100,000 individuals
Signs/Symptoms: pleuritic chest pain, pulsus paradoxus, decreased stroke volume,   decreased inspiratory systolic blood pressure
Diagnostics: ECG: global ST elevation, PR depression, effusion on echocardiogram
Treatments: Treat underlying cause; pericardiocentesis for large effusions, NSAIDs

Pathophysiology: Diffuse thickening of pericardium with possible calcifications leads to decreased diastolic filling and decreased CO.
Epidemiology: Incidence 0.76 cases per 1,000 person-years
Signs/Symptoms: JVD, orthopnea, peripheral edema), Kussmaul sign
Diagnostics: Cardiac catheterization shows equal pressure in all chambers,  pericardial calcifications on CXR, CT/MRI pericardial thickening
Treatments: NSAIDs, colchicine, corticosteroids; surgical excision of pericardium

Pathophysiology: Pericardial effusion resulting in greatly decreased CO, acute pericarditis,chest trauma, etc
Epidemiology: 2 cases per 10,000 population in the United States
Signs/Symptoms: Dyspnea, tachycardia, tachypnea; JVD, pulsus paradoxus
Diagnostics: Enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR. ECG: low voltage, sinus tachycardia; electrical alternans
Treatments: Immediate pericardiocentesis

Pathophysiology: Inflammatory reaction in heart limited to cardiac muscle
Epidemiology: 10 to 20 cases per 100,000 persons
Signs/Symptoms: Patient may report history of recent upper respiratory infection; pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, S3 or S4 heart sound, possible diastolic murmur, possible friction  rub
Diagnostics: ST- and T-wave changes on ECG, conduction abnormalities,  cardiomegaly on CXR, myocardial biopsy shows myocyte inflammation
Treatments: Treat the underlying cause

Pathophysiology: Post-streptococcal-A valvular infection
Epidemiology: Incidence is low in the United States because of antibiotic treatment.
Signs/Symptoms: Migratory arthritis, hot and swollen joints, subcutaneous nodules on extensor surfaces, Sydenham chorea, erythema marginatum
Diagnostics: Increased ESR, CRP, WBC count; 90% of patients have antistreptococcal antibodies, increased PR interval on ECG
Treatments: NSAIDs, use corticosteroids,  b-lactam (penicillin family) in severe carditis

Pathophysiology: Bacterial infection of endocardium with or without valve involvement
Epidemiology: Common in patients with congenital heart defects, intravenous drug abuse, or prosthetic valves
Signs/Symptoms: arthralgias, new murmur, Osler nodes, Janeway lesions,splinter hemorrhages, Roth spots
Diagnostics: Increased ESR; increased CRP, congestion consistent with septic emboli and right-sided heart failure on CXR
Treatments: long-term (4 to 6 weeks) IV antibiotics (initially broad spectrum, then bug specific

Pathophysiology: HTN that by definition has no identifiable secondary cause. Accounts for >95% all cases of HTN
Epidemiology: Risk factors: family history of HTN, high-salt diet (especially if salt sensitive), tobacco use, obesity, increased age; blacks . whites
Signs/Symptoms: Headache, blood pressure >140/90 mm Hg; arteriovenous nicking  cotton-wool spots, or  flame hemorrhage on funduscopic examination; loud S2, possible S4
Diagnostics: systolic B.P >140 mm Hg and/or diastolic B.P >90 mm Hg
Treatments: Weight loss, exercise, salt restriction, smoking cessation, and alcohol reduction, Thiazide diuretic, calcium channel blocker, ACE-I

Pathophysiology: Localized dilation of aorta (>3cm)
Epidemiology: Tobacco use, age >55 years, atherosclerosis, HTN, family history
Signs/Symptoms: Lower back pain; pulsating abdominal mass, abdominal bruits; hypotension and severe pain occur with any rupture
Diagnostics: US/CT/MRI for detection of location and size
Treatments: Surgical repair, if symptomatic or >5.5 cm diameter in men or >5.0 cm in women

Pathophysiology: Congenital defect resulting in opening of ventricular septum allowing shunting of blood
Epidemiology: 2-6 of every 1000 live births
Signs/Symptoms: Frequent respiratory infections, pansystolic murmur at lower left sternal border, loud pulmonic S2, systolic thrill
Diagnostics: Left and right ventricular hypertrophy, echocardiogram shows shunt
Treatments: Diuretics or ACE-I

Pathophysiology: Opening in atrial septum allowing movement of blood between atria
Epidemiology: Incidence worldwide is 56 per 100,000 live births
Signs/Symptoms: Cyanosis, heart failure symptoms, strong impulse at lower left sternal border, wide fixed split S2, systolic ejection murmur at upper left sternal border
Diagnostics: Right axis deviation, echocardiogram shows dilated RV and large heart, increased pulmonary vascular markings caused by pulmonary HTN seen on CXR
Treatments: Possible Antibiotic prophylaxis before surgery or dental work; surgical closure for symptomatic defects

Pathophysiology: Failure of ductus arteriosus to close after birth, Left-to-right shunt
Epidemiology: Risk factors: prematurity, high altitude, first-trimester maternal rubella, maternal prostaglandin administration; females>males
Signs/Symptoms: Asymptomatic, heart failure symptoms, continuous “machinery” murmur, loud S2, bounding pulses
Diagnostics: LVH,  cardiomegaly on CXR; echocardiogram shows large left atrium (LA) and LV; angiography confirms diagnosis
Treatments: indomethacin induces closure; surgical closure if unresponsive

Pathophysiology: VSD, RVH, overriding aorta, RV outflow obstruction
Epidemiology: Risk factors: Down syndrome, cri-du-chat syndrome, trisomy 13 and 18
Signs/Symptoms: Cyanosis, children squat for relief during hypoxemic episodes; systolic ejection murmur, RV lift, single S2
Diagnostics: Right axis deviation, boot-shaped heart on CXR
Treatments: PGE to maintain PDA; O2, propranolol, IV fluids, morphine, knee-to-chest positioning during cyanotic episodes; surgical correction

Pathophysiology: Parallel pulmonary and systemic circulations; aorta connected to RV; pulmonary artery connected to LV,
Epidemiology: Risk factors: Apert syndrome, Down syndrome, cri-du-chat syndrome, trisomy 13 or 18
Signs/Symptoms: cyanosis after birth; cyanosis worsens as PDA closes; loud S2
Diagnostics: Narrow heart base, abnormal pulmonary markings on CXR; echocar-diogram used for diagnosis
Treatments: Keep PDA open with prostaglandin E; balloon atrial septostomy to widen VSD; prompt surgical correction

Pathophysiology: Failure of the tricuspid valve to form accompanied by ASD, VSD, and right ventricular hypoplasia
Epidemiology: Prevalence of 0.3-3.7% in patients with congenital heart disease.
Signs/Symptoms: Cyanosis, holosystolic murmur from the VSD
Diagnostics: Echocardiography shows the defect(s)
Treatments: Surgical correction

Pathophysiology: Pulmonary veins fail to empty into the left atrium and instead empty into the systemic venous circulation
Epidemiology: Incidence of TAPVC ranges from 0.6 to 1.2 per 10,000 live births
Signs/Symptoms: Cyanosis, respiratory failure, shock; may have systolic and diastolic murmur, hepatomegaly from right ventricular heart failure
Diagnostics: Echocardiogram or angiography used for diagnosis
Treatments: Surgical correction

Pathophysiology: Malformation of atrioventricular valves, atrial septum, ventricular septum during fetal development
Epidemiology: Found in 20% of children with Down syndrome
Signs/Symptoms: ASD, heart failure symptoms, pneumonitis; murmurs consistent with a particular defect
Diagnostics: ECG: left axis deviation, echocardiogram or cardiac catheterization used for diagnosis
Treatments: Surgical correction

Pathophysiology: Infection of middle ear caused by S.pneumoniae, H.influenzae, M. catarrhalis ,S. pyogenes, or viruses
Epidemiology: 256/1000 person-years, Increased risk in children secondary to shorter and more horizontal ear canal than in adults;
Signs/Symptoms: Ear pain, decreased hearing; bulging tympanic membrane with decreased mobility, poor light reflex, otorrhea
Diagnostics: Patients history and clinical examination
Treatments: Supportive care, amoxicillin for 10 days

Pathophysiology:
“swimmer’s ear”
Infection of ear canal caused by S.aureus, Pseudomonas, or S. epidermidis; frequently associated with water in ears
Epidemiology: Increased risk in swimmers
Signs/Symptoms: painful, swollen ear with white discharge; ear canal is red and swollen; tenderness of pinna
Diagnostics: Patient's history and clinical examination
Treatments: Topical polymyxin, neomycin, and hydrocortisone; oral cephalosporins, ciprofloxacin for Pseudomonas infection topical drying agents for recurrent infection

Pathophysiology: Vertigo caused by a dislodged otolith in the inner ear that interferes with semicircular canal stabilization
Epidemiology: The lifetime prevalence of BPPV id 2.4%
Signs/Symptoms: Brief, episodic vertigo, Nystagmus, Dix-Hallpike maneuver
Diagnostics: Dix-Hallpike maneuver on clinical examination, CT or MRI can rule out intracranial lesion4.
Treatments: Physical maneuvers designed to free otolith from semicircular canal can alleviate recurrent episodes

Pathophysiology: Vertigo caused by distension of the endolymphatic compartment of the inner ear
Epidemiology: worldwide incidence 12/1,000 people.
Signs/Symptoms: Acute vertigo, decreased hearing, feeling of ear fullness, tinnitus
Diagnostics: Audiometry shows low-frequency hearing loss
Treatments: anticholinergics, antiemetics, and antihistamines, salt restriction and thiazide diuretics, surgical decompression

Pathophysiology: Benign tumor of Schwann cells of CN VIII
Epidemiology: Incidence of 0.3 to 1 per 100 000 population per year.
Signs/Symptoms: Hearing loss, dizziness, tinnitus; unilateral facial palsy; decreased sensation may be seen on examination
Diagnostics: Sensorineural hearing loss on audiometry, MRI can localize the tumor
Treatments: Surgical excision,

Pathophysiology: Severe psychosis that causes significant limitations in functional ability
Epidemiology: Begins in late adolescence or early adulthood, family history, maternal malnutrition, or illness during pregnancy, etc
Signs/Symptoms: Delusions, Hallucinations, Disorganized thoughts or speech, Disorganized or catatonic behavior, Negative symptoms.
Diagnostics: Diagnosis requires the presence of two or more symptoms for at least 1 month within a 6-month period and impaired social function for >6 months.
Treatments: Antipsychotics, Psychotherapy

Pathophysiology:
Psychosis characterized by at least two of the symptoms
of schizophrenia concurrent with a major depressive or manic episode
Epidemiology: lifetime prevalence of only 0.3%, men=women
Signs/Symptoms: Paranoid thoughts. delusions, hallucinations, catatonia, speaking too quickly, depression or irritability.
Diagnostics: at least two of the symptoms of schizophrenia
Treatments: Antipsychotic drug, psychotherapy, CBT

Pathophysiology: Experience of significant depression that lasts  >2 weeks and impacts social and/or occupational function
Epidemiology: most common mental health disorder
Signs/Symptoms: Feelings of sadness, hopelessness. angry outbursts, irritability, loss of interest, sleep disturbances
Diagnostics: Presence of five of the following symptoms lasting>2 weeks; Depressed mood, .Anhedonia, Change in sleep patterns, feelings of guilt, Fatigue, inability to concentrate, changes in appetite, Psychomotor retardation or agitation, suicidal ideation
Treatments: Psychotherapy, Pharmacologic therapy, Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)

Pathophysiology: Cyclic episodes of depression and mania (or hypomania) that impair the patient’s ability to function
Epidemiology: bipolar disorders are most common in persons younger than 25 years. The mean age at symptom onset is 18 years in bipolar I disorder and 22 years in bipolar II disorder.
Signs/Symptoms: Elevated, expansive mood, grandiosity, pressured speech, decreased need for sleep, flight of ideas, increased goal-oriented activity
Diagnostics:
Bipolar I: at least one manic episode; episodes of major depressive 
Bipolar II: at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode.
Treatments: Mood stabilizers, atypical antipsychotics, Lithium

Pathophysiology: Experience of recurrent, spontaneous panic attacks with associated fear that these episodes will occur
Epidemiology: Begins in late adolescence.
Signs/Symptoms: Recurrent, unexpected panic attacks that last up to 30 minutes, chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, diaphoresis, nausea, dizziness, paresthesias, etc
Diagnostics: History of recurrent episodes plus a persistent fear that attacks will happen again.
Treatments: CBT, SSRI's, benzodiazapines

Pathophysiology: Excessive,  persistent anxiety  that occur more days than not for  >6 months and impairs ability to function
Epidemiology: Women 2x > men, typically begins in early adulthood.
Signs/Symptoms: Restlessness or feeling “on edge,” fatigue, inability to concentrate,  muscle tension, sleep disturbance
Diagnostics: excessive anxiety for most days, impairment of ability to function, and three of the symptoms listed above for >6 months
Treatments: CBT; SSRIs or SNRIs; buspirone

Pathophysiology: Excessive fear or anxiety about social situations
Epidemiology: Early onset in childhood or early adolescence and generally becomes chronic. Common (12% lifetime incidence)
Signs/Symptoms: Panic attacks, patients avoid these situations and have a persistent fear of being embarrassed.
Diagnostics: History and examination
Treatments: CBT, SSRIs (First Line)  β-Blockers

Pathophysiology: Presence of obsessions and/or compulsions that cause impairment in function and affect daily life
Epidemiology: Prevalence of 2-3% in the US
Signs/Symptoms: Stressful events can exacerbate compulsive behaviours. Patients are aware of compulsive behaviours but feel unable to control them.
Diagnostics: Presence of obsessions or compulsions that significantly affect daily life
Treatments: CBT, SSRIs

Pathophysiology: Preoccupation with a perceived defect in physical appearance that limits ability to function; typically begins in adolescence
Epidemiology: typically begins in adolescence
Signs/Symptoms: The patient performs repetitive behaviours) related to the concerns about his or her appearance.
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination
Treatments: Psychotherapy, Antidepressants

Pathophysiology: Complex syndrome of symptoms that occurs following psychological trauma
Epidemiology: female-to-male lifetime prevalence ratio of 2:1
Signs/Symptoms: Intrusive memories; recurrent, distressing dreams; flashbacks,  Avoidance of activities, Persistent negative alterations in cognition associated with the event.
Diagnostics: History and examination
Treatments: CBT, SSRI or SNRI; atypical antipsychotics

Pathophysiology: Falsification of physical or psychological signs or symptoms of a disease or injury in the absence of clear benefit to the patient
Epidemiology: The majority of children affected are <5, ~85% of the time the mother is the perpetrator.
Signs/Symptoms: The patient reports symptoms or signs of a given disease and attempts to induce the disease process
Diagnostics: Signs/Symptoms projected on another that is feigned, or fraudulent. Individual Presents the victim as ill, with no obvious external reward. tend to have recurrent episodes
Treatments:
Psychotherapy, limited medical care, CPS often involved. 
Consider Video EEG while hospitalized as a means of capturing abuse on film.

Pathophysiology: An eating disorder characterized by a distorted body image, Intense fear of gaining weight or reduced caloric intake relative to energy requirements
Epidemiology: Risk factors: adolescence, high socioeconomic status; 90% of cases are women
Signs/Symptoms: low body weight, severe body image disturbance, amenorrhea, cold intolerance, hypothermia, dry skin, bradycardia
Diagnostics: Weight loss, electrolyte abnormalities, bradycardia. See DSM-IV criteria in links
Treatments:
Inpatient: fix electrolyte abnormalities, AVOID REFEEDING syndrome. Stabilize and transfer to inpatient psych, or with good outpatient plan. 
outpatient: multidisciplinary approach with pcp, therapy, nutritionist. intensive outpatient management. remember to hide the scale from the patient at visits!

Pathophysiology: Eating disorder characterized by binge eating, Inappropriate compensatory behaviors, Unhealthy preoccupation with weight and body shape
Epidemiology: sociocultural pressures to be thin and the promotion of dieting appear to increase risk.
Signs/Symptoms: Dental enamel erosion, scars on hands, parotid enlargement and oligomenorrhea.
Diagnostics: Bingeing–compensation episodes occur at least once a week for >3 months
Treatments: Nutritional counselling; psychotherapy, SSRI's TCAs

Pathophysiology: Eating disorder characterized by uncontrollable episodes of binge eating without inappropriate compensatory behaviours
Epidemiology: high risk-group: 15–19-year-old girls
Signs/Symptoms: Overweight or obese due to excessive caloric intake
Diagnostics: uncontrollable episodes of binge eating without inappropriate compensatory behaviors
Treatments: psycotherapy, SSRIs

Pathophysiology: Severe, persistent impairment in social communication and interpersonal interactions
Epidemiology: genetic heritability of ASD range from 40% to 90%. In utero risks include valproate (Depacon) exposure, maternal infections, traffic-related air pollution, and pesticide exposure
Signs/Symptoms: Emerge between six and 12 months of age. In many cases, a reliable diagnosis can be made by 24 months of age. Symptoms are impaired social interactions and communication, restricted behaviors
Diagnostics: Important to screen at well-child visits. MCHAT at 18-24 months of age.
Treatments: Behavior, speech, and social psychotherapy, antipsychotics. Refer to multidisciplinary team.

Pathophysiology: Disorder of inattention and hyperactivity in school-aged children that causes prob-lems in multiple settings
Epidemiology: Risk factors:  two to four times more common in males than females
Signs/Symptoms: Inattention: decreased attention span,difficulty following instructions, care-lessness in tasks, easily losing items, forgetfulness, poor listening, Hyperactivity and impulsivity: fidgetiness etc.
Diagnostics: Six inattention symptoms or six hyperactivity or impulsivity symptoms
Treatments: Behavioral therapy, methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, α2-Adrenergic agonists, and TCAs

Pathophysiology: Chronic tic disorder beginning in childhood; associated with ADHD and OCD
Epidemiology: one in five children has had a tic at some point in the first 10 years of life. three to nine times more frequent in males than in females. mean age of onset 6-7 years.
Signs/Symptoms: Multiple motor (e.g., blinking, twitching, etc.) and vocal (e.g., sounds, words) tics that occur every day and worsen with stress; location, frequency, etc
Diagnostics: Presence of tics for >1 year and beginning before patient is 18 years of age
Treatments: Behavioural therapy, fluphenazine, pimozide, or tetrabenazine, SSRIs and α2-agonists

Pathophysiology: Repetitive disruptive and antisocial behavior that violates others’ rights and social norms
Epidemiology: onset during either childhood or adolescence.
Signs/Symptoms: Aggressive behaviour toward people or animals, destruction of property,deceitfulness
Diagnostics: DSM-IV Criteria: Symptoms repeatedly manifest (3 or more of the criteria) in the last 12 months, or 3 or more within 6 months (see links for full list of symptoms)
Treatments: Psychotherapy involving family and parent management training; psychostimulants

Pathophysiology: Hypoxemia resulting from submersion in some type of fluid, usually water, or aspiration of any type of liquid. Causes pulmonary damage
Epidemiology: 3rd leading cause of death, accounting for 7% of all injury-related deaths. 4000 deaths annually in US.
Signs/Symptoms: Dyspnea, cyanosis, decreased consciousness; the patient may not be breathing or  cardiac arrest
Diagnostics: limited and primarily focuses on respiratory function, get CORE body temp, electrolytes and CXR often normal.
Treatments: Secure airway and perform resuscitation; supplemental O2, nasogastric tube placement, maintenance of adequate body temperature

Pathophysiology: Injury to epithelial surface and deeper tissues caused by exposure to significant heat, radiation, caustic chemicals, or electrical shock
Epidemiology: 500,000 people a year seek burn care in the US. 92% outpatient
Signs/Symptoms: According to the degree of burn
Diagnostics: Rule of 9s; Assess dehydration.
Treatments: Cooling and cleansing, topical antimicrobials, intravenous [IV] hydration, wound care, possible escharotomy, Plastic reconstructive surgery with skin grafting may be needed.

Pathophysiology: Aspiration of foreign body into trachea or bronchi preventing normal gas exchange
Epidemiology: Food is a common cause in all ages; toys, coins, and other small objects are common in children.
Signs/Symptoms: Gagging, coughing, or wheezing that progresses to stridor with increased severity of obstruction
Diagnostics: CXR useful in identifying the item and determining location, bronchoscopy may visualize the item
Treatments: Calm the patient, Heimlich maneuver, tracheotomy, Rigid bronchoscopy, IV corticosteroids

Pathophysiology: failure of thermoregulation processes (peripheral vasodilation, thermal sweating, cardiac changes)which are activated by core temperature increases < 1°C (1.8°F).
Epidemiology: heat-related illness in U.S. high school athletes is approximately 9,000 cases annually-- football season. 3rd leading cause of death in high school athletes
Signs/Symptoms: Confusion, blurred vision, nausea, no or little sweating
Diagnostics: Substantially elevated, Increased WBC, increased BUN, increased creatinine
Treatments:
Evaporative cooling, benzodiazepines; antipyretics are not effective
Heatstroke is a medical emergency, and mortality can approach 10 percent

Pathophysiology: Body temperature <95°F/35°C from cold exposure
Epidemiology: Risk factors: alcohol intoxication, elderly
Signs/Symptoms: decreased body temperature, Lethargy, shivering, confusion; arrhythmias, hypotension
Diagnostics: ECG: J waves, Vtach or Vfib
Treatments: Warm patient externally or internally, treat arrhythmias and hypotension

Pathophysiology: Heat gain overwhelms the body's mechanisms of heat loss,
Epidemiology: 2.7/10,000 soldiers, primarily exertional
Signs/Symptoms: Body temperature >104, Confusion, blurred vision, nausea, no or little sweating
Diagnostics: Substantially elevated, Increased WBC, increased BUN, increased creatinine
Treatments: Evaporative cooling (spray naked patient with lukewarm water and then fan) or whole-body cold water immersion; benzodiazepines if seizures are present; antipyretics are not effective

Pathophysiology: Characterized by local tissue damage involving hemorrhage, blistering, myonecrosis and inflammation
Epidemiology: 4.5–5.4 million people a year
Signs/Symptoms: Pain and swelling at bite, progressive dyspnea, toxin-induced DIC
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination, labs: CBC, coagulation studies, etc
Treatments: Immobilize extremity and cleanse wound; antivenin likely required

Pathophysiology: Complex mix of toxins that affect the nervous system (neurotoxins)
Epidemiology: The incidence of scorpion stings 18.7 per 1000 for the 15-month period
Signs/Symptoms: Severe pain and swelling at site of sting, increased sweating, vomiting, diarrhea
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination, “tap test
Treatments: Antivenin, atropine, phenobarbita

Pathophysiology: The venom causes the nervous system to dump all of its neurotransmitters
Epidemiology: 2600 are reported to the National Poison Data System (NPDS) annually. More common in warm environments
Signs/Symptoms: Muscle pain and spasms, localized diaphoresis, abdominal pain, autonomic stimulation
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination
Treatments: Local wound care, benzodiazepines, antivenin

Pathophysiology: Venom is toxic and can cause cutaneous necrosis, is also somewhat cytotoxic and hemolytic
Epidemiology: highest incidence between April-October
Signs/Symptoms: Increasing pain at site, possible ulceration and necrosis
Diagnostics: History and examination
Treatments: Local wound care, dapsone to prevent tissue necrosis, limited benefit of steroids

Pathophysiology: Hypoxemia that results from inhalation of carbon monoxide from car fumes, smoke, or paint thinner
Epidemiology: CO poisoning are currently estimated at 137 cases and 4.6 deaths per million, respectively
Signs/Symptoms: Headache, dizziness, myalgias; cherry red lips, mental status changes,  hypotension
Diagnostics: Increased carboxyhemoglobin on ABGs; normal pulse oximetry
Treatments: 100% O2, hyperbaric O2 therapy; may require intubation

Pathophysiology: overdose depletes glutathione stores in the liver. hepatotoxicity may occur following ingestion of greater than 7.5 to 10 grams (g) (eg, 24 regular-strength or 15 extra-strength caplets or tablets) over a period of 8 hours or less.
Epidemiology: Often used for intentional overdose.
Signs/Symptoms: Nausea, hepatic insufficiency
Diagnostics: acetaminophen level, electrolytes, kidney function tests, amylase, lipase, LFTs, CBC, coagulation factors.
Treatments: Induced vomiting, charcoal, gastric lavage, diuretics, antidote (N-acetylcysteine), supportive care

Pathophysiology: persist in circulation for up to 24 hours, and may cause delayed or recurrent coronary vasoconstriction.
Signs/Symptoms: Tachycardia, agitation
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination, Serum electrolytes,
Treatments: Induced vomiting, charcoal, gastric lavage, diuretics, supportive care

Pathophysiology: Excess activating mu and kappa receptors in the CNS and periphery. resulting in respiratory depression and eventually death
Epidemiology: 70% of drug overdose deaths
Signs/Symptoms: Pinpoint pupils, respiratory depression
Diagnostics: Serum electrolytes, Blood ABGs, RFTs, LFTs, arrhythmias on ECG,
Treatments: Induced vomiting, charcoal, gastric lavage, diuretics, antidote (Naloxone), supportive care

Pathophysiology: Leads to lifethreatening hemorrhage
Signs/Symptoms: Excessive bleeding, easy bruising
Diagnostics: PT and INR raised, LFTs
Treatments: Induced vomiting, charcoal, gastric lavage, diuretics, antidote (Vitamin K, FFP), supportive care

Pathophysiology: Increased activation of GABA receptors resulting in increased frequency of Cl channel opening leading to membrane hyperpolarization and decreased cellular excitation
Signs/Symptoms: Sedation, respiratory depression
Diagnostics: Serum electrolytes, Glucose, BUN, Creatinine clearance, Ethanol level, Acetaminophen level.
Treatments: Induced vomiting, charcoal, gastric lavage, diuretics, antidote (Flumazenil), supportive care

Pathophysiology: Increase in metabolites may cause encephalopathy or cerebral edema.
Epidemiology: widely used in antifreeze in cars
Signs/Symptoms: Ataxia, hallucinations, seizures, sweet breath
Diagnostics: Calcium oxalate crystals in urine
Treatments: Antidote (Ethanol), Dialysis, supportive care

Pathophysiology: Competes with other minerals in cellular systems Ca and Zn thus disrupting several cellular processes that depend on these minerals.
Epidemiology: over 400,000 deaths in the United States every year
Signs/Symptoms: Peripheral neuropathy, anemia
Diagnostics: Serum levels of lead, microcytic hypochromic anemia on CBC, Blood smear shows sideroblasts
Treatments: Induced vomiting, charcoal, gastric lavage, diuretics, antidote (Succimer, dimercaprol, EDTA), supportive care

Pathophysiology: poisons cellular function by altering the tertiary and quaternary structure of proteins and by binding with sulfhydryl and selenohydryl groups.
Epidemiology: human exposure to mercury is caused by outgassing of mercury from dental amalgam, ingestion of contaminated fish, or occupational exposure, according to the World Health Organization
Signs/Symptoms: Renal insufficiency, tremor, mental status changes
Diagnostics: Blood levels of Hg, Urine analysis, radiology for elemental ingestion
Treatments: Induced vomiting, charcoal, gastric lavage, diuretics, antidote (dimercaprol), supportive care

Pathophysiology: Cellular toxicity due to impaired oxidative phosphorylation and mitochondrial dysfunction resulting in metabolic acidosis
Epidemiology: age younger than five years, low socioeconomic status, living in housing built before 1978, and use of imported food, medicines, and pottery.
Signs/Symptoms: Nausea, constipation, hepatotoxicity
Diagnostics: history and clinical presentation, serum iron levels raised, Abdominal radiographic examination
Treatments: Induced vomiting, charcoal, gastric lavage, diuretics, antidote (Deferoxamine), supportive care

Pathophysiology: Chromosomal deletion in 22q11 resulting in thymic and parathyroid hypoplasia
Epidemiology: 1/3000–6000 births, equally distributed between males and females
Signs/Symptoms: Tetany and facial abnormalities, evidence of congenital heart disease;
Diagnostics: Decreased serum calcium,  absence of thymic shadow on CXR, genotyping for chromosomal abnormality
Treatments: Calcium, vitamin D, thymic transplant, bone marrow transplant, IVIG or prophylactic antibiotics

Pathophysiology: Abnormal B-cell differentiation resulting in low B-cell and antibody levels; X-linked disorder with boys experiencing recurrent bacterial infections after 6 months of age
Epidemiology: X-linked disorder with boys experiencing recurrent bacterial infections after 6 months of age
Signs/Symptoms: Multiorgan infection, sepsis, anemia, pneumonia, growth retardation
Diagnostics: No B cells in peripheral smear;  low total Ig levels
Treatments: IVIG, antibiotics, supportive pulmonary care

Pathophysiology: Specific IgA deficiency because of abnormal immune globulin production by B cells
Epidemiology: Increased incidence of respiratory and gastrointestinal infection
Signs/Symptoms: Bronchitis, chronic diarrhea, oral infections, conjunctivitis, GI inflammation
Diagnostics: Decreased IgA, normal levels of other immune globulins
Treatments: Prophylactic antibiotics; IVIG

Pathophysiology: Defect in T-cell CD40 ligand resulting in poor interaction with B cells,
Signs/Symptoms: Oral infections, mucosal ulcers, sclerosing cholangitis, neurodegeneration, hepatobilliary carcinomas
Diagnostics: Decreased IgG, IgA, Hgb, Hct, platelets, and neutrophils, increased IgM,
Treatments: IVIG, prophylactic antibiotics; bone marrow transplant

Pathophysiology: X-linked disorder of immune development with susceptibility to opportunistic pathogens; associated with eczema and thrombocytopenia
Epidemiology: 1-10 cases per million males worldwide, rare in females
Signs/Symptoms: Recurrent infections in presence of eczema and easy bleeding;
Diagnostics: Decreased platelets and IgM, genotyping detects abnormal WASP gene
Treatments: Splenectomy, antibiotic prophylaxis, IVIG, bone marrow transplant

Pathophysiology: An autosomal recessive disorder of ATM gene causing cerebellar dysfunction, cutaneous telangiectasias
Epidemiology: Prevalence is approximately one in 40,000-100,000 live births
Signs/Symptoms: Telangiectasias and ataxia develop after 3 yr of age; recurrent pulmonary infections decreased WBCs decreased IgA
Diagnostics: Decreased WBCs, decreased IgA
Treatments: IVIG and prophylactic antibiotics

Pathophysiology: Defect in which neutrophils cannot digest engulfed bacteria, resulting in recurrent bacterial and fungal infections
Epidemiology: 1 infant per 200,000-250,000 live births.
Signs/Symptoms: Cutaneous, pulmonary, and perirectal abscess formation; chronic lymphadenopathy;
Diagnostics: Patient's history and clinical examination, genotyping detect causative genetic mutations
Treatments: Prophylactic antibiotics, g-interferon, corticosteroids, bone marrow transplant

Pathophysiology: Defect in neutrophil chemotaxis, T-cell signaling, and overproduction of IgE
Epidemiology: inherited, autosomal dominant
Signs/Symptoms: Chronic dermatitis, recurrent skin abscesses, pulmonary infections; coarse facial features,  retained primary teeth
Diagnostics: Increased IgE, increased eosinophils, defective chemotactic response of neutrophils on stimulation
Treatments: Prophylactic antibiotics; skin hydration and emollient use

Pathophysiology: Autosomal recessive dysfunction of neutrophils resulting in recurrent bacterial and fungal infections; associated with abnormal platelets, albinism, and neurologic dysfunction
Epidemiology: Fewer than 500 cases have been reported in the literature
Signs/Symptoms: Seizures, delayed development, musty odor, behavioural and psychiatric disorders
Diagnostics: Large granules in granulocytes on peripheral smear, neutropenia and hypergammaglobulinemia
Treatments: Prophylactic antibiotics, bone marrow transplant

Pathophysiology: A viral infection affecting the anterior horn of the spinal cord
Epidemiology: 125 cases caused reported globally in 2019
Signs/Symptoms: Flaccid paralysis, muscular atrophy, loss of reflexes, paresthesia
Diagnostics: Isolation of virus from CSF, throat swab and stool test, four-fold titer on serologic test, CSF reveals leukocytosis and mildly raised proteins
Treatments: Analgesics, physiotherapy, muscle relaxants, antibiotics

Pathophysiology: All tracts on one side of cord are defected
Epidemiology: Incidence is 30-40 per 1,000,000 people
Signs/Symptoms: Ipsilateral loss of vibration, discrimination and spastic paresis (below lesion), ipsilateral flaccid paralysis (level of the lesion), contralateral loss of pain and temperature (below lesion)
Diagnostics: Patient's history and clinical examination
Treatments: Treat the underlying cause, high-dose steroids

Pathophysiology: (aseptic meningitis), Meningitis caused by a viral infection
Epidemiology: Incidence of 11 per 100,000 population per year
Signs/Symptoms: Neck pain, photophobia, rash; symptoms generally milder than for bacterial meningitis
Diagnostics: LP helpful for diagnosis; viral culture will confirm etiology
Treatments: Empiric antibiotics, supportive care usually sufficient for confirmed viral cases

Pathophysiology: Inflammation of brain parenchyma caused by viral infection or immunologic response to viral infection
Epidemiology: 3.5 and 7.4 per 100,000 patient-year, slight male predominance
Signs/Symptoms: Headache, neck pain, decreased consciousness; change in mental status, focal neurologic deficits, Skin lesions (HSV virus), Parotid swelling (mump)
Diagnostics: Increased WBCs and normal glucose on LP, Brain biopsy for definitive diagnosis, CT/MRI show an inflamed region of brain
Treatments: Maintain normal ICP, supportive care; Antivirals

Pathophysiology: Head and facial pain in trigeminal nerve distribution
Epidemiology: Incidence about 4-5/100,000/year up to 20/100,000/year after age 60. The female-to-male ratio is about 3:2.
Signs/Symptoms: Sudden severe pain in distributions of maxillary and mandibular branches; “trigger zone” stimulation may induce pain
Diagnostics: MRI may identify lesions related to nerve compression
Treatments: Carbamazepine, anticonvulsants; surgical decompression of nerve may be helpful

Pathophysiology: Acute focal neurologic deficits caused by temporarily impaired vascular supply to the brain
Epidemiology:
Risk factors: HTN, DM, CAD, tobacco, hyperlipidemia,
hypercoagulable states
Signs/Symptoms: Paresthesias, amaurosis fugax/other vision abnormality, impaired coordination, vertigo, Carotid bruits suggest carotid atherosclerosis
Diagnostics: US to quantify degree of carotid or aortic stenosis; brain ischemia on CT/MRI, MRA/CTA  to locate intracranial vascular defects
Treatments: Treat other underlying disorders, Antiplatelet (e.g., ASA) and antilipid (e.g., statins) therapy, Carotid endarterectomy/ angioplasty performed for carotid narrowing,

Pathophysiology: Acute focal neurologic deficit lasting >4 hr, caused by ischemia of brain via impaired perfusion (i.e., ischemic stroke) or hemorrhage (i.e., hemorrhagic stroke)
Epidemiology: older age, male sex, nonwhite race, presence of congestive heart failure or coronary heart disease, and family history of myocardial infarction or stroke. Most risk factors for stroke are associated with atherosclerosis.
Signs/Symptoms: Focal neurologic deficit lasting >24 hrs, Constellation of symptoms depends on location of pathology
Diagnostics: CT/MRI useful to differentiate ischemic from hemorrhagic stroke; MRA or CTA for locating ischemic cause, ECG for new onset arrhythmia
Treatments: Treat the cause, Thrombolytic therapy, Antiplatelet therapy, Heparin or LMWH, Lipid-lowering drugs, Reversal of anticoagulation, control of blood pressure, and control of ICP, Surgical decompression may be considered for collections causing decreased consciousness Physical therapy

Pathophysiology: Bleeding between the pia and arachnoid meningeal layers
Epidemiology: mean age 50-55, black Americans > white Americans, females more at risk of aneurysmal hemorrhage than males.
Signs/Symptoms: Severe headache, neck pain, loss of (or decreased) consciousness, seizure
Diagnostics: LP shows red blood cells, xanthochromia, and increased pressure, CT  shows blood in the subarachnoid space; MRA/angiography to localize site of bleeding
Treatments: Prevent increase in ICP, reverse anticoagulation, anticonvulsants

Pathophysiology: Collection of blood between dura and skull caused by arterial hemorrhage
Epidemiology: usually after head injury (73% of cases)
Signs/Symptoms: “lucid interval”, severe headache, decreased consciousness, hemiparesis, hemiplegia, seizures, “blown” pupil
Diagnostics: CT shows convex hyperdensity compressing the brain at site of injury; adjacent skull fracture
Treatments: Emergent drainage of hematoma either under radiographic guidance or by surgical burr hole; stabilization of ICP and blood pressure

Pathophysiology: Collection of blood between the dura and arachnoid meningeal layers
Epidemiology: 1-5.3 cases per 100,000 population
Signs/Symptoms: Slowly progressive headache (days to weeks); change in mental status, contralateral hemiparesis, increased (DTRs)
Diagnostics: CT shows concave hyperdensity compressing the brain that does not cross the midline
Treatments: Surgical drainage or supportive therapy depending on size of bleed and extent of neurologic deficits

Pathophysiology: Repetitive or unremitting seizures without any period of regained consciousness
Signs/Symptoms: Uninterrupted seizures lasting >20 minutes
Diagnostics: CBC, glucose, electrolytes, toxicology, LFTs, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and creatinine. EEG5 shows the prolonged abnormal electrical activity
Treatments: Treat underlying disorder. Maintain airway, breathing, circulation (ABCs)b, IV benzodiazepines  phenytoin

Pathophysiology: Idiopathic dopamine depletion
Epidemiology: 1-2 per 1000 of the population
Signs/Symptoms: “Pill-rolling” tremor of hands, bradykinesia, masklike facies, shuffling gait, “cogwheel” rigidity, memory loss, difficulty  initiating movement, postural instability
Diagnostics: clinical diagnosis, looking for 4 key symptoms:  Rest tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity and loss of postural reflexes
Treatments: Dopaminergic agonists, MAO-B inhibitors, anticholinergic agents Deep brain electrical stimulation

Pathophysiology: Degeneration of anterior horn cells and corticospinal tract
Epidemiology: a precise, single etiology of sporadic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is unknown. 90-95% of cases are sporadic, with the remainder being familial.
Signs/Symptoms: Asymmetric progressive weakness in the face (e.g., tongue, dysphagia) and limbs, change in personality, increase or decrease in DTRs, spasticity, positive Babinski sign, flaccid paralysis
Diagnostics: El Escorial criteria; EMG shows widespread muscular denervation and motor block,  CT/ MRI to rule out neurologic lesions
Treatments: supportive care

Pathophysiology: Autosomal dominant disease caused by multiple CAG repeats on chromosome 4;
Epidemiology: Incidence1.2 per 100,000
Signs/Symptoms: Chorea, dementia (e.g., irritability, antisocial behavior); seizures
Diagnostics: Genotyping will detect chromosome 4 abnormality, CT/MRI shows caudate nucleus atrophy
Treatments: Dopamine antagonists  genetic screening can be used in asymptomatic family members with proper counseling

Pathophysiology: Progressive demyelinating disease of brain and spinal cord with autoimmune etiology
Epidemiology: Most patients are women 20 to 40 years of age
Signs/Symptoms: Vertigo, vision abnormalities, paresthesias, urinary retention, poor movement control, dysarthria, postural instabilities, spasticity, positive Babinski sign.
Diagnostics: CSF: increased protein, mildly increased WBCs, oligoclonal bands, increased IgG, MRI shows multiple asymmetric white matter lesions
Treatments: corticosteroids, methotrexate, and avoidance of stress may help decrease length of exacerbations; interferon-b and glatiramer acetate decrease frequency of exacerbations; supportive care for worsening neurologic dysfunction

Pathophysiology: Post-traumatic cystic degeneration of spinal cord
Epidemiology: Prevalence about 8.4/100,000 people, men>women
Signs/Symptoms: Loss of pain and temperature sensation, flaccid paralysis, decreased DTRs, fasciculations
Diagnostics: MRI shows syrinx expansion
Treatments: Surgical decompression; shunting may be needed for recurrent cases; supportive care

Pathophysiology: Antibodies  bind to acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction and block normal neuromuscular transmission,
Epidemiology: Most common in young adult women
Signs/Symptoms: Periodic weakness, muscle fatigue ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria;  dyspnea in severe case
Diagnostics: Positive ACh receptor antibodies; Tensilon test, nerve stimulation and EMG are helpful in making a diagnosis
Treatments: Anticholinesterase agents, thymectomy, immunosuppressants, plasmapheresis, IV immunoglobulin for refractory cases

Pathophysiology: Autoimmune demyelinating disorder of peripheral nerves associated with recent viral infection, surgery, or vaccination
Epidemiology: 0.4 to 1.7 per 100,000 population
Signs/Symptoms: Rapid bilateral weakness “stocking-glove” distribution with decreased sensations, neuropathic pain, severe cases may include respiratory muscle weakness.
Diagnostics: LP shows increased protein with normal pressure and glucose, EMG consistent with widespread demyelination
Treatments: Self-resolving within 1 month; plasmapheresis/IV immunoglobulin  analgesia

Pathophysiology: Facial weakness (usually unilateral) affecting both the upper and lower face
Epidemiology: 0.4 to 1.7 per 100,000 population
Signs/Symptoms: Unilateral facial muscle weakness/paralysis (asymmetrical smile, drooling, ptosis, inability to close the eye, inability  to raise eyebrow)
Diagnostics: History and clinical examination
Treatments: supportive care (artificial tears, patch the eye), high-dose glucocorticoids, valacyclovir

Pathophysiology: Autosomal dominant disorder (NF1 gene on chromosome 17) with multiple neurologic tumor and dermatologic manifestations
Epidemiology: 1:2600 to 3000 individuals
Signs/Symptoms: Café-au-lait macules.15 mm diameter, neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma, Axillary or inguinal freckling, optic glioma, (i.e., Lisch nodules, Bone lesions
Diagnostics: Clinical examination and medical history, Genetic testing detects abnormal gene, MRI: increased signal intensity in brain and increased brain volume
Treatments: Therapy directed at maintaining function and treating complications

Pathophysiology: Childhood seizures between 6 months and 6 years of age associated with fever
Epidemiology: 1 in 25 children in the population
Signs/Symptoms: Fever >102°F/38.9°C with a rapid rise in temperature; tonic–clonic seizure lasting <15 minutes
Diagnostics: LP should be performed if meningitis suspected or in children, EEG usually normal, unless atypical seizure
Treatments: Antipyretics

Pathophysiology: Autosomal recessive disorder caused by the absence of hexosaminidase A
Epidemiology: Risk factors: Ashkenazi Jews, French Canadians
Signs/Symptoms: Poor development, decreased alertness, hyper-acute hearing; cherry red spots on retina, progressive paralysis, vision loss, change in mental status
Diagnostics: Decreased hexosaminidase A activity; DNA analysis confirms diagnosis
Treatments: Supportive care; genetic screening may aid parents with future childbearing decisions

Pathophysiology: Disorders of motor function resulting from CNS damage during in utero or infantile development
Epidemiology: Risk factors: prematurity, intrauterine growth restriction, birth trauma, neonatal seizures or cerebral hemorrhage, multiple births, chorioamnionitis
Signs/Symptoms:
Spastic CP has multiple limbs with increased tone, increased DTRs, weakness, gait abnormalities, and frequent mental retardation.
Dyskinetic CP have choreoathetoid, dystonic and dysarthria, 
Both types of CP can include hyperactivity, seizures, or limb contractures
Diagnostics: MRI may be useful for detecting causative lesions
Treatments: Botulinum toxin, dantrolene, baclofen, etc, physical therapy, bracing, and surgery can be used to alleviate contractures and improve function, Speech therapy

Pathophysiology: Malignant tumor of the retina in children
Epidemiology: Some cases have a genetic link that increases risk of tumor for both eyes.  The most common intraocular tumor in children
Signs/Symptoms: Patients experience decrease in vision or eye inflammation;  poor red light reflex in affected eye (i.e., leukocoria) or white retinal mass
Diagnostics: Mutation of RBI gene apparent on genotyping, US and CT detect size and extent of tumor
Treatments: Enucleation performed for large tumors, radiotherapy for bilateral tumors or tumors near optic nerve. Cryotherapy or laser photocoagulation, Chemotherapy

Pathophysiology: Interruption of the sympathetic nerve supply to the eye
Epidemiology: approximately 1.42 in 100 000 patients younger than 19 years
Signs/Symptoms: Ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis
Diagnostics: Medical history and clinical examination
Treatments: Treat the cause, cosmetic surgery, phenylephrine

Pathophysiology: Gradual bilateral increase in IOP
Epidemiology: Prevalence 3.54% for ages 40–80,  Risk factors: increased age, increased IOP, blacks, DM, myopia, family history
Signs/Symptoms: Gradual loss of visual fields, halos seen around lights, poor adaptation to changes in light; cupping of optic disc
Diagnostics: IOP testing (i.e., tonometry) shows increased pressure
Treatments: Topical  b-blockers,  a-adrenergic agonists, Laser surgery, Prevention

Pathophysiology: Acute increase in IOP secondary to narrowing of anterior chamber angle and  obstructed drainage of aqueous humor from the eye
Epidemiology: Risk factors: increased age, Asian, hyperopia, dilated pupils (e.g., low-light  environments, optometry examination dilation)
Signs/Symptoms: Severe eye pain, blurred vision, halos seen around lights, nausea, and vomiting; eye is inflamed, hard, dilated and nonreactive pupil
Diagnostics: Tonometry demonstrates increased IOP
Treatments: Timolol, apraclonidine, and pilocarpine eye drops, oral/IV acetazolamide or IV mannitol, Laser iridotomy

Pathophysiology: Atrophic (slow) or exudative (rapid) degeneration of the retina
Epidemiology: Risk factors: white, tobacco, family history, increased age, prolonged sunlight exposure, HTN; female>male
Signs/Symptoms: Gradual loss of vision, loss of retinal pigmentation and hemorrhage  in macular region, retinal detachment
Diagnostics: Fluorescein angiography shows neovascular membranes and retina
Treatments: Vitamin C, vitamin E, b-carotene, copper, and zinc, intravitreal ranibizumab, laser photocoagulation

Pathophysiology: X-linked chromosomal disorder associated with mental retardation in males; females may be carriers and rarely show any effects of the abnormal gene
Epidemiology: 1 in 2500-4000 males and 1 in 7000-8000 females
Signs/Symptoms: large face with prominent jaw and large ears; mild hand and foot abnormalities, macroorchidism; mental retardation, hyperactivity,  seizures
Diagnostics: Medical and family history, clinical examination, genotyping
Treatments: appropriate genetic counseling for parents, symptomatic treatment

Pathophysiology: deletion of Entire 5p chromosome arm
Epidemiology: 1 in 20,000 to 1 in 50,000 newborns
Signs/Symptoms: High-pitched, catlike cry, small head, low birth weight, mental retardation
Diagnostics: Genotyping shows deletion of chromosome 5p, Medical and family history, clinical examination
Treatments: Symptomatic treatment

Pathophysiology: deletion of 7q11.23
Epidemiology: Prevalence is one in 10,000-20,000 births in the United States.
Signs/Symptoms: “elfin facies”, short stature, mental retardation, cheerful/friendly personality, supravalvular stenosis
Diagnostics: Medical and family history, clinical examination, Genotyping show deletion of maternal allele
Treatments: Symptommatic treatment,

Pathophysiology: 15q11-15q13 (deletion of paternal allele)
Epidemiology: Prevalence of 10,000 to 20,000 living individuals in the US, equal distribution in men and women
Signs/Symptoms: Overeating, obesity, decreased muscular tone in infancy, mental retardation, small hands and feet
Diagnostics: Genotyping shows deletion of 15q11-15q13
Treatments: Symptomatic treatment

Pathophysiology: 15q11-15q13 (deletion of maternal allele)
Epidemiology: Prevalence 1 in 12,000-20,000 in the general population
Signs/Symptoms: Puppetlike movement, happy mood, unprovoked laughter, mental retardation, seizures
Diagnostics: Genotyping show deletion of maternal allele, Medical and family history, clinical examination
Treatments: Symptomatic treatment
